SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to various bounty Acts.

The Bill's major purpose is to amend the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 to continue the computer bounty scheme for a further five years to 31 December 1995, but with some programmed changes to the bounty rate to align it with other general reductions in protection. The other amendments in this Bill to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984, Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 and Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Act 1990 are of a minor technical nature and are explained in greater detail in the clause notes to schedule 1 of the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

The proposed extension of the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 reflects this Government's strong commitment to encouraging the development and utilisation of computer based technologies as outlined in the Government's information industries strategy announced in September 1987. In fact, the bounty is a significant factor supporting the thrust of the strategy which is to foster the development of internationally competitive and technologically advanced industries which pay greater attention to product research and development, innovation and marketing.

The OECD estimates that the information industries account for some 14 per cent of world trade and are growing much faster than world trade generally. The Australian information technology market was valued at $10.8 billion in 1989 and is forecast to more than double by the early l990s.

The previous bounty scheme as provided for by the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 expired on 5 July 1990. This scheme in turn succeeded the ADP equipment bounty scheme introduced in 1977. The original bounty rate of 25% on the value-added in local production was reduced to 20% in the 1986 Budget and this is the rate which has operated since then.

I mention this historical fact of a bounty being paid on computer based equipment to demonstrate that successive Australian governments have supported through means which have included a bounty, the development of an internationally competitive manufacturing industry and the need to improve the productivity and the competitiveness of all industry sectors by the wider application of information processing technologies. Indeed these objectives are central to the continued bounty scheme which this Bill provides for.

The bounty will continue to be paid to eligible producers of computer based equipment, covering mainly computers, microprocessor based controllers and regulators, modems and multiplexers, hybrid circuits, integrated circuitry, and systems software associated with eligible items.

The bounty has been instrumental in the development of a number of industry sectors including computer manufacturers, manufacturers of engineering, medical and scientific equipment incorporating microprocessor based programmable controllers, application specific integrated circuits, hybrid circuits, and electronic funds transfer point of sale equipment, this latter area being one in which Australia is a world leader.

The bountiable items are incorporated into a wide range of user applications in almost all industry sectors, including automotive, telecommunications, consumer electronics, scientific and medical, banking and finance, transport and tourism.
Due to the expiry of the previous computer bounty on 5 July 1990, this Bill provides for continuation of the new bounty scheme from that date.

The computer bounty addresses, in particular, two key areas of the information industries strategy. Firstly, the need to continue Australian industry's efforts in information technology product research and development. Successful commercialised research and development in Australia provides manufacturing with an edge necessary for exploitation in a highly competitive market. The high technology nature of the information industries makes reliance on research and development imperative to compete effectively in the major markets.

The Bureau of Industry Economics (``BIE'') in its ``Program Evaluation Report No. 8-The Computer Bounty Scheme'' released on 22 February 1990, pointed to the high proportion of research and development undertaken by the bountiable goods sector. The sector is a strong R& performer with an average R& intensity (the ratio of R& expenditure to turnover) of 9%, far in excess of the manufacturing average of 1%.

The BIE concluded that the bounty has contributed to the substantial level of R& expenditure occurring within the sector which it assessed had increased from $13 million in 1985/86 to $33 million in 1988/89.

While it is recognised that Australia is at the forefront with other industrialised nations in the taking up of computer based technologies, a judgment as to whether a diffusion of the bountiable technologies to user industries is satisfactory must remain subjective. It would be impossible to attribute increased usage totally to the bounty scheme, nevertheless the Government is satisfied that the bounty has had a major positive impact.

The BIE's analysis has found that the sector involved in the manufacture of bountiable equipment had, on average, experienced a 25% sales growth per annum since the bounty's inception. This compares with sales growth in manufacturing as a whole of around 10% per annum over the same period, suggesting that the bounty has been influential in encouraging the development of new products which have sold very successfully on the market.

Of course, movements in the Australian dollar have also been a factor as the sector is very sensitive to competition both here and overseas. However, in the absence of the bounty it is certain that the industry would be much smaller and less vibrant than it is today.
The second key area of the information industries strategy in which the computer bounty plays an important role is the enhanced international integration of these industries.

The sector's primary orientation lies in the production of goods for niche markets rather than for the mass market. These goods, therefore, have a degree of customisation which allows production volumes to be smaller and marketing more directed in a fiercely competitive market environment.

The BIE's analysis shows the computer based equipment industry to be an outstanding export performer. Its export propensity has averaged between 39 and 51 per cent over the past four years. This is more than double the export propensity of manufacturing as a whole which is about 21%. The sector's exports increased from some $66 million in 1985/86 to $141 million in 1988/89.

The coverage of the bounty has been seen by some as a potentially problematic area, both in terms of its budgetary impact and perceptions about who should benefit from the bounty. Suggestions to limit eligibility have included:
. restrictions on the types of products eligible for bounty
. excluding foreign multinationals on the basis that Australian taxpayers should not subsidise them

. removing from eligibility those ``screwdriver'' operations where product development is not carried out in Australia, or where manufacturing activity is based only on assembly of imported built-up components
. putting upper limits on bounty claims to exclude those larger operations which should not need assistance
. putting lower limits on bounty claims to exclude smaller firms and thereby reduce administrative costs; and
. qualifying entry depending on export and/or R& levels

However, there is no economic justification for such restrictions. Restricting eligibility to Australian owned firms would distort commercial decisions as many transnational subsidiaries operate no differently from their Australian counterparts, and are faced with the same tariff input costs on imported components. To base eligibility on firm size would create anomalies associated with the degree of specialisation in bountiable products or the degree of in-house manufacturing. Uneconomic behaviour would most likely result as firms attempt to regain eligibility.
In addition, administration of such restrictions would become increasingly subjective and administrative costs would increase substantially due to additional requirements.
The Bill provides for the rate of bounty to be adjusted under the new bounty scheme to:
. 7% from 6 July 1990;
. 15% from 1 July 1991;
. 13% from 1 July 1992;
. 11% from 1 July 1993; and
. 9% from 1 July 1994 to 31 December 1995

This phasing down of the bounty rate will maintain the relationship between the effective rate of assistance for the bountiable goods sector and that of manufacturing generally (excluding the passenger motor vehicles and textiles, clothing and footwear sectors) and takes into account the general tariff reductions program announced in the Government's 1988 May statement.

As I have previously highlighted, the computer bounty is a significant element of the Government's information industries strategy; and industry, both locally and foreign owned, closely identifies the Government's decision to continue the bounty with its commitment to the development of this important group of industries in Australia.

Continuation of the bounty for five years to 31 December 1995 effectively demonstrates this Government's commitment to these industries and provides a time frame for industry to adjust to the decreasing levels of assistance.

Importantly, continuation of the bounty as provided by this Bill will effectively mean that Australian manufacturers and users of computer based equipment and technologies will continue to have access to these at close to world prices, and thereby will be encouraged to continue the process of transition to increased levels of international competitiveness.

TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (RATES AND PROVISIONAL TAX) BILL 1990
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 7, page 2, lines 28 to 32, leave out the definition of ``provisional tax uplift factor'', insert the following definition: `` `provisional tax uplift factor', in relation to a year of income, means, until the Parliament otherwise provides, 10%.''

During the debate last night I commented on the principles relating to standing charges by virtue of examples of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill and the Income Tax Amendment Bill imposing those taxes.

I now advert to this particular matter of the provisional tax uplift factor. This has been at 10 per cent for the last five or six years. Clearly, this level has been generally accepted. It simply wastes the chamber's time to impose a particular level each year.

The amendment also rejects the Government's proposition that we give the Government authority to be able to amend the level by regulation. If the Government wants to change the standing charge of 10 per cent, we think it must come back to Parliament. The amendment clearly states `until the Parliament otherwise provides'.

All other taxes are introduced and legislated for in a similar manner. The sales tax, the fringe benefits tax, the withholding tax and income tax rates are all there as standing charges until an amendment is moved. If the Australian Democrats and the Opposition wish to move amendments to tax legislation, there is ample opportunity. Many tax Bills come in each year. There is no substance in the argument that this imposition of a particular rate of withholding tax uplift must be brought in by a separate Bill each year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I mentioned last night, the coalition is deeply concerned about the Australian Democrats' change in philosophy since the days of Don Chipp and Janine Haines. Those people thought that standing charges bypassing the Parliament was somewhat abhorrent. After all, it was the Democrats who came here with that great slogan that swept across Australia and gave that Party some credibility-`we are here to keep the bastards honest'. Nowadays, the Democrats are here as the lap-dogs of the Australian Labor Party. For years and years the Labor Party has been trying to introduce Bills to impose standing charges. That is the purpose. The Democrats are now doing the work for the Government; they are no longer an independent, vibrant force looking at the rule of Parliament, upholding the sovereignty of law.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night I mentioned that two Democrat members, Senator Janet Powell and Senator Coulter, have in the past abhorred that practice. To their credit, they are not in the chamber listening to this debate today. No doubt they are squirming; no doubt they feel somewhat embarrassed by the predicament in which Senator Spindler has put them.

I find it quite outrageous that the Democrats say that this is the acceptable level of the past. Are they so divorced from the problems of the Australian community nowadays that they cannot see that this economy is in recession? Yet, henceforth they will put a standing figure of 10 per cent on all provisional taxpayers. Are they not aware that business profits are declining and that small businesses are going to the wall and becoming bankrupt?

True, they say, we can go back and apply for a variation of provisional tax. Dear oh me, have they not heard about the problems of taxpayers' rights, the problems of incontestability, the problems of retrospectivity and the problems of reverse onus of proof? They are not worried about these issues any longer; they are just going along as the lap-dogs of this Labor Party. They should be ashamed of themselves. I make an apology to the new members of the Australian Democrats. They are new; they are not aware of the consequences that they are being led into. Perhaps, with the passing of time, they may change next year. I can assure honourable senators that the coalition will be ever vigilant to ensure that these matters are not enshrined either in regulation or put in the form of standing charges.

Senator Spindler even had the temerity to say that parliamentary scrutiny is a waste of time. Is that not an absolute disgrace? We have heard comments about the irrelevance of Parliament and parliamentarians. Yet the people who are supposed to be the watchdogs and keep people honest are not prepared to be the watchdogs any longer. They believe that this parliamentary process is a waste of time.
The Opposition will certainly be voting against this Bill. We deplore the fact that the Democrats voted against our amendment last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support my colleague Senator Watson on this point that he has so well put. I did not think I would ever see a Party such as the Australian Democrats. If I might divert from that point-when former Senator Haines decided to run for a lower house seat in the House of Representatives and lost, I was probably one of the ones that cheered the most in Western Australia. But judging by how the Australian Democrats are operating on this Bill and the rabble that has gone on since the last election, I would like to see her come back.
—You want to see her back!

—For me to admit that I would rather see her back is really saying something. I did not think that I would ever listen to a debate encouraging the bypassing of parliament, especially from Senator Spindler, who should have learnt many things in his time in Australia that he may not have known before. He is probably used to places where parliament is bypassed.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government wants to bypass parliament because it has egg on its face from last year. It decided on an uplift of about 10 per cent or 11 per cent-it may have even been 12 per cent-but, unfortunately, in its haste to run out to the electorate and get itself elected in the few weeks that the figures were looking somewhere near right, it forgot to put it through parliament. So it was not able to enforce that uplift last year. It is as simple as that.

What was the Government's reaction? It brought in a Bill to make the process an ongoing one, and the Democrats have fallen for the three-card trick and will support the Government on the 12 per cent, or whatever it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong. You had better read it.

—Whatever the figure is, the Democrats have been taken in hook, line and sinker. If this Bill is passed we will have a fixed uplift every year until Parliament changes it again. As Senator Short pointed out, businesses in Australia-the ones that pay provisional tax, and most businesses pay provisional tax-are not doing very well. If a business had a negative income this year and a positive one last year-
—You can get a variation.
—I know that, and I am coming to that. I am glad that Senator Spindler interjected. There will be an uplift whether the business has gone backwards or not.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Spindler comes in with the great argument-and this privilege has been around for 30 years that I know of personally-that one can ask for a provisional tax variation. One can do that; but what he does not tell us, and what the Government does not spell out either, is the penalty if one miscalculates.

I saw Government members and Senator Faulkner smirk last night in here when this very argument was canvassed, I think, by Senator Short. Senator Faulkner had a smirk across his face because of penalties which may apply if the calculations are incorrect. I suppose that Senator Faulkner was smirking because he was thinking that the taxpayer should be able to forecast the likely income pretty accurately. The taxpayer can do all the calculations he likes-and provisional tax has to be calculated, if one wants to get a variation, by the end of March of every year-and do accurate figures up to date of provisional tax pay date, but his calculations can be thrown out by one event.

Probably the Democrats, not being very well represented in the remote areas, would not know this, but I can give an example. Most income can be controlled-one can control wool sales and income from other sources-but the Australian Wheat Board could make a payment to growers that has not been announced in March. That has happened-it has come in with a payment on 28 June, throwing the calculations out of kilter, but that is no defence against penalties for understating or miscalculating provisional tax. The Democrats never considered that one. Because of what I heard last night, I am glad that Senator Spindler made that interjection.
I heard Senator Kernot interject on Senator Watson that it is a waste of time to be listening to this debate. It certainly is not a waste of time to be debating this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—Senator Kernot, like me, was elected to this place to serve the constituents of Australia. If she thinks it is a waste of time listening to the debate, she could at least remove herself from the chamber and, better still, remove herself from this Parliament. On that point I will close my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned also that this 10 per cent uplift should be enshrined in legislation, which means that it becomes very difficult and time consuming if it is to be changed every year. Those of us who have paid provisional tax most of our working lives understand what a burden it is. I wonder-as former Senator Siddons has left the Australian Democrats-whether there are any Democrats around now who have ever paid provisional tax in their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not criticise the fact that union organisers-which a lot of my colleagues in the chamber are-academics, teachers or public servants, all of whom are in very honourable professions, do not pay provisional tax if they get a regular wage. They get their wages whether the economy is good, bad or indifferent. Their wages do not have to rise and fall with the economy of the day, and their income does not depend on how much they produce for Australia. Those of us who do make produce for Australia, and who do, in fact, contribute to Australia's overall wealth, are those running their own businesses-small business men-who have to pay provisional tax. It is those people whom this sort of legislation affects. I just wonder how many of the Democrats have ever paid provisional tax, and how many of them-
Australian Democrat senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is probably one. They are not in a position where they work for themselves, where they are in small business and doing something productive for the country, instead of just sitting there getting the same regular salary whether the economy is good, bad or indifferent. If they were small business men, and if they did do something productive for the country, they would know just how difficult this provisional tax really is. It is a great burden for those of us who have run our own businesses in the past.
—Particularly when incomes are going down.

—I thank Senator Baume. It is okay, I suppose, when things are rosy, but not when things are difficult. If this rate is set at 10 per cent and it is not under the scrutiny of Parliament every year, we will find that small business men have this extra charge every year automatically. The taxation uplift should be related to the state of the economy at the time, and a real estimate of what the income is likely to be in the next year for small business men. I challenge anyone to suggest to me that next year small business men will be getting 10 per cent more in their taxable income than they are getting this year. If this year they get the same as they got last year, it will be a remarkable event, with the way the economy is at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is outrageous for the Democrats to want to enshrine this in legislation. I can understand members of the Australian Labor Party doing it, because I suspect that none of them have ever been in a position where they have had to pay provisional tax themselves. But it is amazing and incredible that the Democrats should be supporting this legislation, taking the rate away from the scrutiny of Parliament, at a time when the real incomes of those working in small businesses are falling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — First of all, I would like to assure Senator Macdonald that certainly I, having been in small business for 20 to 25 years, have paid provisional tax on a regular basis. I have not found it beyond my faculties to ask for a variation when that was necessary. There seems to be a clear implication that people cannot manage their own financial affairs. The provisional tax is a tax like any other tax, and why should it not be certain for business planning so that one knows, well in advance, what one is likely to pay? Why should one not have to make one's own decisions and arrangements to vary it, if circumstances require it?

SPEECH.PARA: There is another thing that Government and Opposition senators do not seem to be able to do, and that is read. They say the process has been withdrawn from parliamentary scrutiny. The legislation states, `until the Parliament otherwise provides'. Taxation Bills are coming in every year. Has the Opposition so little confidence in its ability to move an amendment to a taxation Bill that it feels it cannot deal with it but must wait for the Government to bring in a Bill-
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —You must wait for the Government to bring in a Bill before you can make any statement on it at all. We are quite confident-
—Senator Spindler, I remind you to direct your comments through the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. We are quite confident that we are able to watch the Government and bring in an amendment when necessary, but that same confidence does not seem to be present on the Opposition benches. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put clearly on the record what this debate on clause 7 is all about. The Government's Bill provides in clause 7 that the:

SPEECH.PARA: `provisional tax uplift factor', in relation to a year of income, means:
(a) the percentage, not exceeding 12%, that is declared by the regulations to be the provisional tax uplift factor for the year of income; or
(b) if there is no such declaration-10%;

That is what is in the Bill now. The coalition, for reasons that have been very eloquently and articulately described by Senator Watson and others last night, some of which have been repeated today, objects violently to that proposition because, as I will come to in a moment, it takes away the basic right of this Parliament to be required automatically to give a decision on a tax rate from one year to another. That is why last night Senator Watson moved on behalf of the Opposition that, instead of the definition of `provisional tax uplift factor' that is now in the Bill, we insert the following definition:
`provisional tax uplift factor', in relation to a year of income, means the percentage (if any) declared by an Act other than this Act to be the provisional tax uplift factor for the year of income;

That amendment was clearly designed, and would have done if accepted, to require the government of the day-this is not a matter of party politics; it is the government of the day whether it is a Labor government or a coalition government-honestly and openly to say to the Parliament, `We are proposing to strike a rate of provisional tax uplift', following which it would be a matter for the Parliament to decide, openly and in the full gaze of parliamentary and public scrutiny.

That amendment of the Opposition was defeated last night by the Australian Democrats supporting the Government, for reasons I will come to in a moment. We are now debating a Democrats' amendment which is basically along the same lines of principle as the Government's provision. It states:
`provisional tax uplift factor', in relation to a year of income, means, until the Parliament otherwise provides, 10%.

In other words, it locks us into a figure of 10 per cent unless something or other is done by the government of the day to suggest another change. Far from what Senator Spindler was saying in his remarks just a moment ago, the Democrats with that amendment are putting absolutely into the Government's hands-not the Parliament's-the decision as to whether there shall or shall not be a variation of that rate of tax. That has exactly the same effect in principle as what the Government has proposed; namely, it takes away from the Parliament the automatic right and requirement each year to take a decision on the tax uplift factor.

Let us be clear; that is what this debate is all about. The Government's proposal takes away from this Parliament the automatic requirement each year to take a decision on a very important rate of tax. The Democrats' amendment is no more than a variation on that. It does not vary the principle at all.

I object to that very strongly for two reasons. The first reason I object to it so violently is that the Bill as it stands, or with the Democrats' amendment, denies the automatic right of elected members of Parliament to do their job; that is, to look at perhaps the most important matter that parliamentarians are required to look at-the rate that is struck for the taxpayers in this country to pay.

I am particularly concerned in this case, in the area of the provisional tax uplift, because it is an extraordinarily difficult job-an almost impossible job-for provisional taxpayers to calculate accurately what their income situation will be 12 months in advance. Over the life of this Government increasingly stiff penalties have been put into the Income Tax Assessment Act for failure to calculate provisional tax correctly. Those penalties basically apply regardless of whether the taxpayer has consciously or with the best will in the world tried to calculate his provisional tax correctly. The fact that the penalties have gone up to such an extent-I am not necessarily complaining about that-adds great weight to the requirement that the Parliament ought to be looking at the uplift factor each year as of automatic right.

As Senator Watson has said, the Democrats when they were first formed set themselves up as the custodians of the moralities of the taxpayers and the electors of Australia. I had never heard such hypocritical nonsense in my whole life, and the whole record of the Democrats has confirmed that it was hypocritical nonsense. Less than three years ago, on 4 November 1987, when a virtually identical provision was being debated in the Senate in the old building, the Leader of the Australian Democrats at that time, former Senator Haines, said-

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is the provision we were debating last night.

—It is, except that the Opposition's proposal last night was defeated by the Government with Democrats support. Now we are looking at an amendment proposed to the same clause by the Democrats. The Democrats are purporting that this is based on some great difference in principle from what the Government's Bill is about, and that is absolute nonsense. Senator Haines, the former Leader of the Democrats, said in an identical debate to this one on 4 November 1987:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the arguments that we are making here is that to give this sort of legislation and, for that matter, the next Bill, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, standing status instead of annual status is, in fact, to deprive this Parliament-
she was referring to the Government's proposal at the time-

of the opportunity of challenging the Government from time to time on a range of taxation, Medicare and other related economic matters, and prevent it from doing it on an annual basis, restricting its opportunities to those years in which the Government is going to make some change to the rates and needs to amend the Income Tax Act accordingly.
She went on to say in the next paragraph:
. . . it is a matter of the rights that honourable senators have to raise issues of importance to all of us and to the community generally.

That is the important point of principle in this Bill. I could not say it better myself than Senator Haines said it less than three years ago. I think I am right in saying that the vote that was taken on that amendment three years ago showed that the Democrats then supported the coalition's view on this matter.

Now what the Democrats have done between then and now, for reasons that absolutely escape me, is a 180 degree turn from that very correct expression of principle that was outlined on 4 November 1987. I find that extraordinary and inexplicable. I must say, without being too much of a critic of the Democrats, that it is absolutely in line with their whole approach to this Parliament. They will blow hot one day on one issue and the next day they will be 180 degrees different. The impossibility of the Democrats as a party seemingly being able to pursue a consistent line of principle in this Parliament is doing this country a great deal of harm, which is enshrined in this amendment that they are proposing. I join Senator Watson and other members of the coalition in rejecting the amendment outright.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did not actually want to prolong the debate on the nonsensical arguments put forward by the Opposition, but I must respond to one particular aspect and that is the position that Senator Haines adopted some three years ago and the position we are adopting now. There is a very clear reason for that, which is, I suggest, that we have acquired a degree of confidence in our ability to move an amendment in this Parliament when an amendment to Government legislation is required. It is a confidence that the Opposition obviously lacks.

SPEECH.PARA: They have lost their right of being an independent. They have lost their right and credibility of being a watchdog of the people. They have lost their credibility of upholding the sovereignty of Parliament. They have lost their credibility of being concerned about this fundamental principle-the need for the rule of law to prevail. The Democrats will not be writing out to small business mentioning their stand on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we will.

—I welcome that, and the challenge is that they will certainly do that, but they will be disgraced in the eyes of ordinary businessmen around Australia for what they have done. It is an absolute disgrace. To say that they have a degree of confidence to deal with these issues is not the point. We are losing the opportunity in this Parliament to review. That credibility has now been lost as a result of what has been proposed today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to return to the provisional tax provisions and the Government rather than the skirmish between the Opposition and the Democrats. The Democrats have shown today that they have no sense of reasoning whatsoever. Provisional tax, even the Government must admit, is a taxing of the future- not necessarily 12 months of the future but at least 3 months of the future. Provisional tax used to be payable by 31 March and now it is payable quarterly for companies paying more than a certain amount and once a year for partnerships. So it is definitely three months into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this provision has been extended by the Government in other ways in superannuation. When this Government came to power in 1983, superannuation was taxed at the end. When one received one's superannuation, a certain amount of tax was payable and then that was turned around and things were taxed along the way. Now we have taxation of the future also with public companies. The bigger public companies have an option of either paying income tax by 28 July with the balance in March or they have the option for the present moment of paying it all in August. It is an ongoing method by this Government to continually tax the future. The Government has taxed Australia out of its brains for the present and now it is taxing the future.

Unfortunately, the Government has been helped by the Democrats. One may vary provisional tax if one's business has not been doing so well. TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not. I said that was rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some issues of importance in this debate. I understand that people are properly concerned and I want to address some of those concerns. Most of the discussion this morning has had nothing to do with those issues of principle. Nevertheless, I will try to refer to them.

I do not believe anybody in this chamber underestimates the significance of proper parliamentary scrutiny, including proper parliamentary scrutiny of taxation. We do not have impassioned debates about the fact that the sales tax rates are set until the Parliament otherwise determines. Of course they are. The income tax rates are set until the Parliament otherwise determines. They are much more fundamental than the uplift factor on provisional tax. I am not minimising the significance of that and I will refer to it in a moment.

The income tax rates are the matters that fundamentally determine the obligations of the taxpayers. They are determined by the Parliament. They are open to variation by the Parliament. To my chagrin, the Democrats will try to change one of them this morning. I intend strenuously to oppose their attempt. Although, not in so many words, the legislation sets the rate `until the Parliament determines', the Democrats are exercising their parliamentary prerogative to try to change it which I am confident they will fail to do. But it does not take away the Democrats right to scrutinise it, to raise it, to review it, to debate it. Let us get that part of the debate into perspective. It is a wildly overstated proposition.

A related question concerns the Bill, although not the Opposition amendment. It deals with the use of regulations in the setting of obligations for taxpayers. Quite clearly, that is not a matter that ought to be taken lightly. I will come back to that in a moment. The Government sought, and would prefer, the power to be able to do that. I understand that honourable senators have raised concerns about that.

In this instance I do not want to minimise the fact that using regulations to change the provisional tax uplift factor has implications for individual taxpayers. It affects how much of their tax obligation they have to pay at a particular time. It does not affect their ultimate obligation as taxpayers to pay tax on their income as finally determined and in accordance with the rates as set. I do not dispute that it affects them because it affects the time at which taxpayers have to pay and how much they have to pay at that time. It has revenue implications for the Government. The corollary of that is that it has expenditure implications for taxpayers. I accept that. It is not a matter that is to be taken lightly.

Principally, the Government was seeking-and had I been able to get agreement in discussion I would have moved a Government amendment-to have the capacity by regulation to be able to reduce that level; that is, for the Parliament to set the cap so that we could not, by regulation, without parliamentary approval increase the level of the obligation but we could, by regulation, reduce it.

I spent some time as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I found it a valuable and educational experience. As a result of being on that Committee, one of the attitudes I developed-which I think is shared by many people in the Parliament-was a concern about proper use of regulation as against legislation. Where the regulation is being used to the benefit of the citizen or the taxpayer, rather than to their detriment, we have a fundamentally different situation. There, the capacity of the Parliament subsequently to disallow can be effective, were a policy question involved, because it gives the Parliament the effective scrutiny that is required.

It is true that any moves in the taxation area by regulation ought to be taken carefully. In this instance what the Government proposed was the preferable course of action. By definition it is the one that the Government would have preferred. We would however prefer the Democrats amendment to that which was previously proposed by Senator Watson, and against which we voted last night.

In agreeing to that amendment, I reiterate that it is not our preferred position but it resolves one of the two problems with which we are trying to deal. That was a problem which caused significant inconvenience to the Government, of course, but to many taxpayers as well.

We often hear passionate expositions in this place about the need for certainty in tax. It is a bit of a mirage. We will never achieve absolute certainty. The most uncertain situation was generated last year by the failure of the Senate to pass that legislation and there being no underpinning situation so that there was a continuing uplift factor when the Parliament failed so to resolve.

That was one of the two things we were trying to resolve. The Democrats' amendment will deal with that. If the Parliament fails subsequently to resolve, we will have an ongoing uplift factor. It does not give us the flexibility to reduce that in response to economic circumstances should the need arise without legislation. That would have been an appropriate flexibility and was properly protected.

This is nothing but a cheap political stunt on a broadcast day for the Democrats to pick up a few cheap votes around the country. It is certainly not going to work because, as we have been told already, the amendment is not going to be supported by the Opposition.

The Democrats idea is to hit those who are high income earners. They have put themselves in that position. They are there to hit them. But it is taking away incentive. As Bernie Fraser of the Reserve Bank of Australia said yesterday, in order to get Australia moving properly we need lower overall tax rather than higher overall tax. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my brief remarks on this amendment, I wanted to comment on precisely the social justice point that Senator Spindler gave as the reason for this amendment in the first place. Let me say at the outset that neither I, the Liberal Party of Australia, nor anyone on this side of the chamber gives any moral high ground whatsoever to Senator Spindler or the Australian Democrats when it comes to the question of social justice. In my book, social justice is about having a large enough cake for everyone in our society to be able to participate in the eating. There can be no true social justice in our country if there is no economic growth, development or rising living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: All of the policies of the Democrats, since their inception, have resulted in the antithesis of economic growth, rising living standards and development. Therefore, the social justice that Senator Spindler speaks so fondly of cannot be achieved. If he were really serious about social justice in this country, he would have an economy which was dynamic, vibrant, growing and allowing living standards for all Australians to rise. What Senator Spindler is proposing in this amendment is contrary to that.

There is an enormous number of problems facing this country. We have the largest economic morass and the biggest danger of economic recession in this country since at least the 1930s. The reasons for that are numerous, but they include, very importantly, the burden that government has put on each and every Australian, particularly Australians who want to save, to invest and to get on with the job of productive investment and growth in this country.

Domestic savings are at rock bottom in this country. The fall in domestic savings is one of the major sources of our problems. As a result, investment is falling like a stone. We have soaring unemployment-we have just seen the start of that. We have falling output. Everything in this country is going the wrong way at the moment in terms of achieving the growth and development that are required. To say that putting a 60 per cent tax on incomes above $60,000 is going to suddenly compound that problem dramatically-

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the amendment: it is $100,000.

It would have detrimental effects because the people in this country who are going to make the cake that provides the social justice which Senator Spindler so fondly talks about are the people in that category, along with a whole lot of other people.

SPEECH.PARA: The sum Senator Spindler mentioned is not a high salary, for a start. He said that $100,000 is something like six times the average weekly earnings. That is simply not true. The figure of $100,000 is about 3 1/2 times the average weekly earnings. Less than 20 years ago the maximum marginal tax rate in this country cut in at a figure of something like 15 to 18 times average weekly earnings.

One of the great problems we have had in this country and the reason why incentives are so rock bottom is that we have increased the burden of tax on each and every member of our community so much that we now have the higher bracket income earners in this country paying the maximum rate of tax which cuts in, at the moment, at 15 per cent higher than average weekly earnings. Twenty years ago it was 18 times higher than that. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell has suggested that the fact that the top one per cent of income earners in Australia control 19.7 per cent of the wealth-and I would say that some of these figures might have gone a bit awry in the last few months-that the top 10 per cent control 55.2 per cent of wealth, and that the top 50 per cent control 98 per cent of wealth is something that is wrong. She has said that it requires an inquiry and that the situation should be changed by taxing people who earn, taxing people who put in effort, ripping off the reward for that effort and redistributing it. There is not very much difference in the philosophies.

We are debating a very significant difference in philosophy. Senator Spindler has suggested that he would raise $600m from this measure. I think it was Senator Panizza earlier who asked what the figure was and what the motivation for bringing in the amendment was. Of course, the motivation is to try to balance what has become known as the fairies at the bottom of the garden Budget. I must say that during the election the fairies might have been at the bottom of the garden, according to Senator Walsh. But it would seem it is not the Bogong moths that have come into the Senate chamber in the last few days, I think the fairies have come into the Senate. These sort of ideas are fanciful, they are crazy. Even the Labor Party, to its credit, over the last seven and a bit years in Government, has come to realise that ripping more and more money out of the productive side of society and redistributing it to the non-productive side is not the way to get this country on its feet.

I ask the Democrats: Can they honestly say that they could rip money out of people who earn and work for the good of this nation, and for their own personal good as well, take that money away and redirect it to all of the social areas that Senator Spindler has gone through-areas like Aboriginal welfare, single mothers pensions, nature conservation and so forth-and spend that money efficiently? I think we are all coming to realise, especially those of us who have seen the welfare state in most of the free world being totally rejected as a way to achieve an efficient economy and, indeed, to achieve efficient delivery of welfare to people in real need, that that is what we really have to talk about. If we look at the money we spend on Aboriginal welfare, on single mothers pensions, on nature conservation, on health and on education we realise that most of the money goes to highly paid bureaucrats. The alternative that the coalition proposes is to allow the spirit of charity, to allow individuals to earn and to achieve, and to look at different ways of delivering these services so the services and the welfare--
Australian Democrat senators interjecting -

TALK.START.PARA: —It's like a canary cage over there.

—I know. They are not fairies, they are canaries. We would allow the welfare to be delivered to the people who really need it, those people who cannot help themselves. We would allow them to receive the benefits of a progressive and an expanding economy.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Short said, if we continue to take away the incentive and take away the motivation from the achievers in this world, we will not have any achievers. We will drag everyone down to the mediocre level that the Democrats would like to see everyone on. I do not believe that everyone is equal. I do not share that view with the Democrats. TALK.START.PARA: —They have a responsibility to society.

What I am suggesting to the Senate, as Senator Short has already said, is that we should allow them to work and to get reward for their work and their effort. We should let them earn $100,000, or $200,000, or $500,000 or $1m. Good on them! Let them do that. Let us not see these redistributionists, these collectivist fairies try to rip that money off. Let us see those people have the freedom to invest those earnings, to create savings and to see the Australian economy expand. That is the crux of this debate, that is the crux of the political argument in Australia now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have now moved from being the centre party to being the party of the loony Left. They have gone out to the left of the Labor Party. The Labor Party has clearly shown in the last couple of years that it is rejecting some of the collectivist ideas that have been so disgraced in eastern Europe and in the recent history of Australia. It is moving to try to make things a little bit freer, it is moving to privatise some of the Commonwealth trading entities. We have to congratulate it for that. We all know that it is not going far enough, but it is moving in the right direction. The whole of the political spectrum in Australia is moving in the right direction and the Democrats are moving out to the loony Left.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the right.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not let it be said that I am sticking up for high income earners. I protect their right to earn high incomes, to invest, to create savings and to help Australia. But what we want to do is ensure that low income earners, people who are on the low tax scales, through freedom in the industrial area, through incentive, can become middle income earners; and middle income earners can become high income earners; and that people who rely on welfare, people who cannot help themselves, through no fault of their own, can get off the tit of government and become less reliant on government.

We talk about caring for the unfortunate people who rely on welfare. How much dignity can people have who have to rely on the whim of government welfare policy from day to day, from month to month? All senators have had inquiries at their electorate offices from people who have been messed around by the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs and who feel, obviously, a great lack of dignity having to go through the bureaucracy to argue about why they did not get an extra $20, or whatever. What sort of dignity can those people have?

The coalition is in favour of ensuring that as many people as possible can look after themselves. The only way we can do that is to create incentive for people to earn, to stop ripping them off as soon as they start achieving and to stop knocking down the tall poppies. Let us see thousands of tall poppies in Australia. Let us see what that does for this nation. Let us make the economic cake bigger and let everyone have a fair share of it.

We do not need an inquiry into wealth distribution in this country. What we need is an inquiry into wealth creation. I am in favour of putting a bit of fertiliser on the Australian garden and growing a few tall poppies, then we will get this place moving. But when we have got these loony Left fairies in the Democrats dragging this country down with their failed 1960s ideological bent let us just shake them off and get on with the job of getting this country on the road again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the very welcome decision of the United Nations (UN) General Assembly to fill Cambodia's United Nations seat with an all-party Supreme National Council (SNC). In view of the significance of this decision, the first unanimous resolution on Cambodia in the United Nations in 11 years, can the Minister advise what stage negotiations have reached between the Cambodian factions on the final composition of the Supreme National Council? Can the Minister also advise when the Paris Peace Conference on Cambodia will be reconvened? Subject to a successful outcome of the Paris Peace Conference, can the Minister also advise when the UN will begin its involvement in the interim administration of Cambodia? Does the Minister have any further information on the likelihood of Australia providing forces for the UN peacekeeping force in Cambodia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October, the United Nations General Assembly in its plenary session adopted a consensus resolution on Cambodia introduced by the President of the General Assembly. Australia very much welcomes the adoption of this consensus resolution, which underlines the now universal international consensus for an end to the Cambodian conflict. The resolution itself welcomes the agreement by all Cambodian parties, which occurred in Jakarta on 10 September, to form the Supreme National Council as the unique and legitimate body and source of authority throughout the transitional period. The resolution notes, importantly, that the SNC is to occupy the seat of Cambodia at the United Nations. Through the Supreme National Council, it is intended that all Cambodians be represented at the UN and that this will put an end to debate over which party or rival government should or should not be entitled to represent Cambodia at the UN.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the state of play in the internal negotiations as to the composition and chairmanship of the SNC, the SNC itself has been formed, I think it is important to appreciate, by agreement of the parties in Jakarta on 10 September, and it met again in Bangkok a week later, but there is yet to be agreement on the question of the chairmanship, the vice-chairmanship and the delegation to the UN. Agreement, I have to say, is not immediately in sight in that respect. We hope that these matters can be resolved quickly to enable the SNC as a result to actually occupy the UN seat.

Australia endorses the call in the consensus resolution for the Cambodian leaders to cooperate in assuming their responsibilities in order to achieve national reconciliation in this first step in particular. I think we all have to accept, however, that such a process will not be easy as the Cambodian parties have been fighting a very bitter civil war for 11 years now and there is a high level of mutual suspicion and distrust. What we and the rest of the international community can do to assist the process is to simply not place too much emphasis on transient alarums and diversions, but work for and continue to support efforts to put the comprehensive settlement together.

As to the comprehensive settlement itself and the movement to put that to bed, it is hoped that at the end of this month or the beginning of November there will be a working group meeting of relevant countries in Jakarta to elaborate the present framework document and to work it up into a final negotiating text. The intention thereafter is that that then be the subject of debate and hopefully acceptance by a full-scale reconvened Paris Conference, meeting at a ministerial level we hope some time early in December, to put the comprehensive settlement to final endorsement.

If all goes according to schedule, there could well be a UN presence in Cambodia as early as the beginning of next year. As to Australia's contribution, I have indicated on a number of occasions that we intend to make a substantial contribution to the UN presence in Cambodia. What precise form that takes will depend on the provisions of the final settlement and on the requirements of the UN, as determined by the Secretary-General. As to a military contribution, Australia would be prepared in principle to make such a contribution but it is not possible at this stage to define what that might be or to define with any precision the numbers that might be involved.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. In view of the series of bus accidents in recent months, what action has the Government taken to make bus travel safer for Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provided with the following information by the responsible Minister, Mr Robert Brown: the Federal Government is taking a leading role in improving bus and coach safety throughout Australia. The Vehicle Standards Advisory Committee has been working since July 1987 on a package of safety improvements for buses and coaches. Australian design rules (ADRs) have already been introduced covering speed limiters, tyres, rollover strength, seat belts for the driver's seat and unprotected seats, and requirements for seat strength and seat anchorage strength. The ADR relating to tyres came into effect on 1 July 1990 and all others will come into effect between 1 July 1992 and 1 July 1993.

ANSWER.PARA: A further regulation on seats and padding has been urgently developed, based on a recent international regulation. This provides a second stage of improvement on seat strength, seat anchorage strength, and padding on long distance coaches. This regulation was endorsed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council at its last meeting and will come into force between 1 January 1992 and 1 July 1992.

The Federal Office of Road Safety, the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority and vehicle and seat manufacturers are cooperating on an urgent test program to evaluate current coach seats. Information obtained from this will assist the Federal Government in its consideration of the question of seat belts in all coach seats as well as the case for even stronger seats.In addition, work is also being done in other important areas, such as anti-lock brakes and emergency exits. This would follow as a further stage of improvement as soon as possible.

The Federal Government is working with the Queensland Government in investigating the bus crash in Queensland and the conclusions drawn from the investigation will help guide further work in the area of bus safety. The introduction of these standards has brought Australia to the forefront of bus and coach standards in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out, in addition to what I said in the Senate the other day, that at the time those decisions are taken there will be a competitor for Telecom. Any decisions taken will be made having regard to the fact that there will be a competitive environment operating in that area. So far as the timing is concerned, as I have said in the Senate on previous occasions, that matter is currently under intense consideration by the Government in respect of the policy changes that were made at the last special conference that the Australian Labor Party had on this issue.
