TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence aware of recent public reports which state that the Department of Defence has been strengthening its relationship with Japan's self-defence forces? Can the Minister comment on the reasons for visits to Japan made earlier this year by Dr Paul Dibb and Vice-Admiral Alan Beaumont? Can the Minister outline for the Senate the Australian Government's views on the potential for a military role for Japan in international relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia and Japan are both alliance partners of the United States and have in common a strong commitment to ensuring peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region. It is important that we understand each other's perceptions of the changing strategic environment and resultant policies. With this in mind, we have sought to expand the range of defence contacts between Australia and Japan to encompass ongoing dialogue on strategic and international security issues of interest to both of us.

ANSWER.PARA: Discussions on security environment are particularly relevant at this time in view of uncertainties created by the changing international situation and the implications of this for the Asia-Pacific region. It was in this context that Dr Paul Dibb and Vice-Admiral Beaumont visited Japan in March. The process of consultation has continued with the visits to Australia of Japanese defence Minister Ishikawa in May and of General Terashima, Chairman of the Joint Staff Council, this week.

As to the latter part of Senator Loosely's question, during his recent visit to Japan the Prime Minister commented publicly that Japan will have a critical contribution to make to the creation of a new world order and that no framework for the conduct of international relations could be regarded as complete if it lacked Japanese commitment and involvement. How Japan chooses to do so is a matter of significant debate within Japan and it would be presumptuous for Australia to intervene in a matter which is essentially for Japan to decide.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It relates to the set-up of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). The question is in four parts. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether, as a consequence of the Australian Securities Commission Act, each and every one of the 800,000-odd companies registered in Australia will be issued with an eight or nine digit corporate identification (ID) number? Will these companies be required to have this number printed on all official stationery, cheques, statements, invoices, receipts, order forms, other official notices, letterheads, and even registration plaques on their doors or foyer walls? If this is the case, will those companies be required to comply with this part of the Act by 1 January 1991? If this is the case, bearing in mind that there are only 47 working days until Christmas, what percentage of the 800,000 businesses which will be affected have been informed of this requirement and of any fines for non-compliance? Did the Government, in coming to this part of the Act, assess the financial impact on Australian small businesses, which will have to meet this extraordinary expenditure at a time when they can least afford it

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator who asked this question will be well aware that, during the Estimates committee process, these questions were posed to the members of the Australian Securities Commission who were available for cross-examination by honourable senators at that time. The answers which were forthcoming will be found in the Hansard of that Estimates committee meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that there will be a requirement for the provision of a particular number by various businesses around Australia; indeed, I think the compliance date is 1 January 1991. It is hoped that businesses will be able to comply by that date, though I am not absolutely sure of the sanctions, results or consequences of non-compliance by that date and what effect that might have on their participation in the ASC scheme.

It is a fact-I think this came out at the Estimates Committee; quite obviously it is a statement only of fact-that there is only a short time between now and 1 January 1991. The witnesses before the Committee made it very clear that the various businesses throughout Australia would need to be given timely advice of their obligations in this regard.

I believe that the honourable senator's question, when asked, led to the response that the number was not required to be put on the full range of stationery that he mentioned, but I would have to check on the exact range of matters which would need to have the stamp of the particular ID number.

Businesses throughout Australia recognise the huge benefits that will flow from their participation in the corporate life of Australia in a situation regulated by the Australian Securities Commission. In fact, for far too long under the National Companies and Securities Commission company life in Australia, corporate life in Australia, was not regulated in a way which was helpful to businesses because it led to a situation where investor confidence in various businesses was undermined by the practices that were indulged in without sufficient surveillance and enforcement activity being undertaken by the joint operation between the Federal Government and the State governments and their various parliaments.

After 1 January 1991, where there will be a simple structure with clear ministerial responsibility, parliamentary responsibility and a well-resourced Australian Securities Commission, I believe that most businesses throughout Australia would recognise that very substantial benefits will flow simply from the change in confidence that will be engendered in the various markets of investors both domestically and around the world and, therefore, some small cost of printing up their stationery with certain numbers will be infinitesimal compared with the benefits that will flow to those businesses from the operations of the Australian Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister referred to the compliance cost I guess in a fairly offhand way.
—Have you about 10 supplementaries?

—No, only two or three. Out of Estimates Committee E, which Senator Tate referred to, I was given an answer by one of the departmental officers that said that they were instituting a process of advising professional advisers of this requirement. All the professional advisers I have spoken to in the last month, and I have spoken to dozens of them about this question--
—Order! Ask the supplementary question, Senator Campbell. You are making a speech.

—Yes, Mr President. The fact of the matter is that accountants have not been made aware of this requirement. The cost of compliance at $100 per company will be about $80m. I ask the Minister: In view of this will he ensure that the 800,000 companies are informed, as they have not been to date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell has, indeed, raised a valid point. I believe it is incumbent on the Australian Securities Commission to ensure that those companies which may be required to comply with this particular very sensible requirement are informed in a timely way of their obligations and in a way which not only allows them to be aware of their legal obligations but also gives them the time to take the commercial and other necessary logistic steps to comply.

ANSWER.PARA: I will ensure that the matters that were raised by Senator Campbell, both in the Estimates Committee and today, are immediately brought to the attention of the Australian Securities Commission and will seek a response to the facts that he has put before the Senate in terms of an inadequate notification campaign being undertaken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the statement made by his predecessor, Senator Don Grimes, in respect of family allowances as distinct from family income supplement, to the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983. Senator Grimes said on behalf of the Government:

QUESTION.PARA: It is often forgotten, however, that family allowances are not and were never meant to be a welfare program in the strict sense. Rather, they are designed to achieve a broad measure of equity in the tax transfer system between those with and those without dependent children. They recognise that at any level of income those with children face higher costs than those without.

Is it a fact that the Government's family assets test proposals represent a back down from the long standing policy based on principle to one which, in effect, imposes a higher tax on families with children to the advantage of those without children and with identical assets? Is it a fact that the family allowance assets test has no regard to income received nor the number of children of a family dependent on that income? Is it also a fact that many families, particularly farm families and those engaged in small business, might be technically asset rich but income poor? Finally, is it a fact that the Government's proposal will affect 100,000 mothers; that 80,000 mothers will lose allowances due to the assets test; that 13,000 mothers will lose allowances due to the removal of the taper or shade-out of allowances; and that 4,000 mothers will lose the family allowance supplement receipts? Are those figures correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do remember the statement that Senator Grimes made at the time that the family allowance was not meant to be-nor is it meant to be now-a welfare payment in the traditional sense of the word but rather an attempt to gain equity for those with children as against those without children. No step that the Government has taken in the course of the last few months ought to be interpreted as moving away from that.

ANSWER.PARA: The tests that we already had in place on income for family allowances suggested that the Government did not believe that there should be no limit on those who were to receive that payment. Once any kind of means testing is introduced, as we did with family allowances, the acknowledgment is that while one is trying to bring about broader equity it is not possible to suggest that that requirement means that every person must receive those allowances. So it was never intended that every mother in Australia would be receiving allowances for her children. The very well off were not to receive them.

What the Government then did in the Budget was to make sure that we introduced some more targeting. This was to make sure that our welfare payments were going to those who needed them. So we had a series of more targeting in the welfare area. When it came to family allowances, we also made sure that people at the top end of the scale who did not need to receive the allowances ceased to receive them. So, if you like, there were some minor changes at the top end.

Because we are mindful of the original statement about broader equity, the assets test was set so high that it does not affect huge numbers of people. I think the numbers that Senator Harradine gave are basically right. Although I did not write all of them down, I will assume, for these purposes, that they are right.

The Government was of the view that when we get to a figure like $300,000 net-which means that they can be much bigger assets and one can take off mortgages and the like-people in that situation are really pretty well off and are not in need of this payment. I would regard that as fine tuning, not as the tearing up of the original ideal. That was the intent of the Government at the time and I do not believe that it represents a back down.

The honourable senator mentioned in particular the plight of those on farms. I think we have to look at both the payment of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement in this respect because changes have been introduced which affect both. As far as those changes are concerned, I think I have indicated in this place that the Prime Minister saw a delegation from the National Farmers Federation which raised this problem. He indicated to members of the delegation that the Government would be prepared to consider a submission from them on this. I am, therefore, hopeful that we will be having that consideration within the two weeks that the Parliament is up. I am pretty sure that they are going to supply it by the end of this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —And small business?

—I am not sure that the Prime Minister has given an undertaking so far as a small business is concerned. He has given it so far as farmers are concerned. Nonetheless, he said he will consider it. I think I have already indicated in answer to another question-and I am happy to tell the Senate when we come back in a couple of weeks time-where the reconsideration is up to.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In the light of earlier comments by Senator Button that major projects have been stalled on economic grounds, does the Minister share the concern of the Executive Director of the Business Council of Australia that 35 per cent of new projects have been so affected at a cost to Australia of $9 billion? If so, what will the Government do to prevent this trend continuing to Australia's great detriment?
—I will refer that question to Senator Button.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of recent media reports that air safety standards will be threatened by the termination of the two- airline policy, which termination takes effect on the 30th of this month? I ask the Minister whether these claims are accurate. If not, can he give assurances to the chamber and to the Australian air travelling public that all things possible are being done to ensure that Australia's commendable air safety record will be protected in the deregulated system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a rash of horror stories about air safety linked with deregulation since the Government announced its intention to terminate the two airlines agreement at the end of this month. I assume that Senator McKiernan was referring to the current affairs program last night, which was a wonderful piece of tabloid television. I did not see it last night; I saw it earlier this morning. It is unfortunate that program, which contained 15 minutes of end-to-end pictures of aircraft being fished out of the Potomac River, aircraft on fire, and dead passengers and broken bodies, did not even attempt to make some sort of realistic comparison between the aviation market of the United States of America and that of Australia. It is something that I have spoken about here in the Senate on many occasions, and will obviously have to speak about on many future occasions. It is very difficult to validly compare the two situations.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also relevant to point out-I will do this now before I go on to talk about the major differences in the Australian deregulation approach-how incredibly safe aviation is in the United States of America. What is constantly left out of the argument are the extraordinary number of miles flown and aircraft movements on a daily basis in the United States where, because of airline deregulation, the percentage of Americans who regularly use air transport has risen from somewhere around 20 per cent to somewhere in excess of 60 per cent because of the benefits that deregulation has brought to the United States.

I give just one brief comparison of the huge difference between the two markets. The amount of traffic conducted by airlines is measured in things called RPKs-revenue passenger kilometres. This year, to give the most recent example, the entire combined domestic fleets in Australia-all single airlines combined, with every single aircraft operating in Australia-flew an average of 33 million RPKs a day. In June this year, one American airline-United Airlines Inc.-flew 460 million RPKs in a day.

There are scores of airlines operating in the United States, all of which would rate the adjective `significant' by Australian standards and most of which would be bigger than any domestic carrier we have got. One airline-United-flew 460 million RPKs compared with 33 million for the entire domestic fleet in Australia. That is the difference between the two markets.

The major difference is that what this Government is doing is moving away from economic regulation of the aviation industry, not moving away from safety regulation of the industry. In fact, I must say that a far more relevant country for A Current Affair to have compared Australia with would have been Canada. The Canadian authorities have taken an approach to deregulation very similar to our own.

After deregulation commences on 31 October this year the Government, through the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), will continue to play a role in the safety regulation of airlines in Australia. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will continue to operate as it does now, reporting directly to me, not through the CAA. A major and comprehensive review of all the regulations governing Australian air safety prior to deregulation is currently being conducted by the CAA in order to make the system more efficient and, if possible, even safer than it currently is. One of the major differences between the United States aviation industry and our own, of course, is the age of the fleet. It is a significant factor in respect of air safety. There are aircraft operating--

TALK.START.PARA: —They keep them longer.
—I beg your pardon?
—Order!
—Mr President, the interjection is nonsense.
—Order! It is making the answer very long, too.

—I will conclude on this point. I do not think I have repeated myself yet. The reality is that the average age of the fleet in Australia, which has one of the youngest fleets in the world, is as follows: Australian Airlines Ltd has a fleet with an average age of six years; Ansett Airlines of Australia, 4 1/2 years; and East-West Airlines Ltd, less than 12 months. The only new entrant to the Australian aviation sector at the end of this year-Compass Airlines-will, in fact, be leasing new aircraft to fly in the Australian aviation industry. To conclude--
—That is why I was late last night.

—Indeed, Senator. Australia has an enviable safety record; we are conscious of that. We are determined to preserve it. The arrangements we are putting into place, with the continued tight regulation of safety, will continue, with safety being the major priority of the Civil Aviation Authority.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer the Minister to the timber mill at Ravenshoe. Is it true that a $350,000 boiler purchased with Commonwealth loan money was sold back to the company and leased back to it while he was the Minister? Is the sale of this item and the sale of a $400,000 veneer mill in breach of a term of the assistance agreement not to dispose of the assets of the company without the Commonwealth's permission? Can the Minister advise where the money for these assets went? Did he, as the responsible Minister, know of the sale beforehand, and did he give permission for the sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to check on what happened during that period. I certainly do not recall authorising any sale, but I will check on those details. As to what the Commonwealth knows about what happened to our money, I have nothing to add to what was in that very long answer I tabled yesterday, which I think is fairly comprehensive. I do not seek to go into any more detail than that. I simply make the point that during the course of the last few days, as Senator Boswell continually asks these question, I hope he is considering that he is putting at serious risk the rescue operation that we have attempted to mount--
—If we expose your comments you will take it out on the people of Ravenshoe. Is that what you are suggesting?

—I will tell Senator Boswell what I am suggesting. I do not need his help. As long as we are going to get irritable today-I need no help from him. The facts are that, if he wants to go out and raise all these things, firstly, he will do me no harm-he never has; he spent three years trying and he is a dramatic failure; and his very young friend behind him has got Buckley's as well. Secondly, I am much more worried about what will happen to the 50 people who are employed up there.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has made an effort and an offer-a very generous offer-to try to continue to keep this place open. All Senator Boswell is doing is attempting to destroy any other means of keeping this on as a going concern. That is what the people of Ravenshoe need and that is what we will attempt to deliver. If Senator Boswell wants a piece of my hide that is fine; he has had plenty of tries. It would have been helpful if he had waited until negotiations with the receiver manager had been completed. But he was not smart enough to do that, nor was he clever enough to realise that he is hurting the interests of those he purports to represent-and, my God, he does a miserable job of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I draw his attention to an article that appeared in the 11 October edition of the Sun-Herald, where the Leader of the Opposition is quoted as saying that the functions of the Department of Social Security could be given out to welfare agencies under a Liberal government. Is the Government planning to increase the role of community and non-government organisations in the provision of social security? What would be the impact upon clients and community based groups providing assistance in the welfare field?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the suggestion made by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson-I got it right this time; I have been practising.
—You didn't get it right with Oakes.
—I have been practising; it is Dr Hewson.
—You need to practise.

—Of all the inane interjections that Senator Walters has managed in the last few years, that goes near the top of the list but it does not quite get there. She has done worse. I have seen the brilliant proposal from Dr Hewson that we privatise social security. I have to say that the Government is not going to consider it. We can see a lunatic proposal when one comes along. We do not need to go into great detail to work out how good or bad it is.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just give a couple of examples as to what it would mean were the Government to adopt it. I wonder what we would say to the two million families that we pay family allowances to, about whom Senator Harradine asked a question earlier. Just imagine them all down at the Brotherhood of St Laurence queuing up to get the payment. What a wonderful performance that would be!

But it goes further. That is just the beginning. When it comes to trying to look after sole parents, one wonders how the Opposition would deliver the jobs, employment and training scheme which has been welcomed by so many of them; how it would coordinate all of the services that go to them. The facts are that it cannot be done. It is a joke. I understand that it has become very dry on the benches opposite. Senator Alston came in here as a wet. Honourable senators will all remember that. It did not last very long because the numbers went the other way and off he jumped. He became dry. This mad rush to be dry is causing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is debating the question and I ask that you call him to order.
—Order! Senator Richardson, you were debating the question. I ask you to answer the question.

—I will seek to do that, Mr President. I accept your suggestion that I should not debate the question. I am concerned that the Government should not consider proposals that are so dry as to seek simply to sell off government and create anarchy. This does no good whatsoever to any Australian in need and most certainly puts all those in need in much harsher circumstances. No welfare agency in the country is equipped to handle the load. All those agencies have said so already. Everyone has rejected this proposal and all we have is Dr Hewson and Senator Alston still running with it. Two out of the 17 million Australians think it is a good idea, and that is about where it will end.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the statement by Mr Keating on 11 March 1990 during the election campaign when he promised the Australian people:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . a returned Hawke Government will deliver real wage increases in each of the next three years.
Does the Government still stand by that promise?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government stands by its election commitments.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to media reports indicating opposition by Michael Mansell, the self-styled secretary of the so-called Aboriginal provisional government, to next week's visit to Australia by Nelson Mandela? In his opposition, Mr Mansell is reported as being critical of the African National Congress (ANC) insistence that its cause is more pressing than his own. Would the Minister care to comment on what I believe is the convoluted logic of this position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have unfortunately seen the press reports of Mr Mansell's comments. I must say that in years and years of watching and listening to Mr Mansell as I have, I think he has done himself a very grave disservice and personal injury with his latest performance. Maybe he needs a long holiday. Mr Mansell said that he anticipates major demonstrations by Aboriginal people in Australia against the visit of Nelson Mandela. I think Mr Mansell's chances of getting massive demonstrations against Nelson Mandela from black Australians are zilch. But I have to say that I am disgusted at Mr Mansell's comments; I think they are disgraceful. It is about time that, with the greatest respect to the Fourth Estate, and I have the greatest respect for the Fourth Estate--
—I don't.
—Well, I do.
—Not their photographers, anyway.

—Maybe if they put me on the front page of the Age I will change my opinion. I do, but I think it is about time that the Fourth Estate started giving Mr Mansell a little less attention every time he delivers this stuff, because he does not represent anybody. He certainly does not represent the Aboriginal people that I know and have known so well. In fact, honourable senators ought to be around in my house and have a listen to my wife when Mansell appears on the television. Funnily enough, she was talking to me about this latest outburst last night.

ANSWER.PARA: What Mr Mansell has said on this occasion is that it is a disgrace for Mr Mandela to accept an invitation from the Australian Government, when in fact it is entirely appropriate for Mr Mandela to do that because the Australian Government has played a major role-and Mandela has acknowledged it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade-in assisting the African people of that country to get some sort of justice in their own country. It is entirely important and entirely appropriate for the Australian Government to act as a host of his visit.

In terms of Mr Mandela's hide, according to Mansell, of considering the plight of black South Africans as greater than his own-that is Mansell's own-I would point out without going into gory detail and speaking at length just one salient factor that seems to have escaped Mr Mansell. Nelson Mandela spent more than 30 years of his life in prison-30 of the best years of his life-because he wanted the majority of the citizens in his own country to have the same rights as the minority have.

Nelson Mandela released a statement which really got to me after his release, and I thought he put the matter very succinctly indeed. He went to prison 30 years ago and what he said was, `Don't think it is all fixed yet, folks'. Nelson Mandela was saying, `Because I am out of prison don't sit back in your straps and think that the good times are ahead, because I went to prison more than 30 years ago and spent 30 years of my life deprived of my liberty and deprived of my normal contact with my friends and family for the right to vote. Thirty years later I came out of prison and I still do not have the right to vote'. Nor do the 70 per cent of black South Africans have the right to vote that Nelson Mandela went to prison for 30 years ago now. I have got to tell the Senate that Michael Mansell has got an enormous hide and an enormous arrogance to suggest that the plight of the South African people is in fact not greater than his own. I do not think Michael Mansell personally has had a hard day in his life-certainly not in the 10 years I have been listening and watching him.

I would, I am sure, enjoy the support of not only all of my colleagues on this side of the house but also on the other side in saying that it is entirely appropriate for the Australian Government to be the host of Mr Mandela's visit. We look forward to his visit here with a great deal of anticipation and welcome. We support the struggle of his fellow South Africans for some rights in their own country and particularly to enjoy the basic right of being part of the democratic process of their own country. I totally reject the outrageous statements made by Michael Mansell.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from Senator McKiernan's question on airline safety, I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support: Will the Government make available to the travelling public adequate information on the maintenance records, as distinct from the safety records, and the number of incidents, as distinct from accidents, of the various domestic airlines so that members of the travelling public can make an informed choice as consumers when they choose to fly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do believe that there would be a slight practical problem in doing that. I do not think it would fit well in the pocket of the seat in front. It would probably take the flight attendants a little long to get the aircraft off the ground to deliver it. The fact is that the kind of detailed information that Senator Kernot is requesting would easily fill this room. The fact also is that that kind of information is available to any member of this Parliament who wants it, any time it is required.

ANSWER.PARA: We had extended hearings of a Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, where these matters were canvassed at length. If Senator Kernot-and I make the offer right here and now; I will turn it on this afternoon-wants a detailed brief on the detailed maintenance regimes of every single aircraft on the Australian register, I will provide it to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and deals with a matter that is of great importance not only to the businessmen and manufacturers who export and import through Cairns but to those who use the major regional ports throughout the rest of Australia. My question is: In view of the fact that labour arrangements at the Cairns port will be a precedent for labour reform in regional ports of Australia, will the Minister assure the Senate that the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority will adopt and implement the conclusions and recommendations of the Interstate Commission Report on Waterfront Investigation by having the Waterside Workers Federation withdraw its coverage at the Cairns port, where it is intended to establish an integrated port labour force? Will the Minister also assure the Senate that he is not, at the behest of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), attempting to influence the Cairns Port Authority to continue to employ at the Cairns port Waterside Workers Federation members who are unable to be usefully employed? Will the Minister also confirm that the Waterside Workers Federation stevedoring labour will not be treated preferentially by making redundant existing Cairns Port Authority workers who are members of the Australian Workers Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I cannot see Question Time out with this one I am not trying. I have been waiting six months to get a question on the port of Cairns from a Queensland senator and this is the first question I have had in six months, when in fact the situation in Cairns has now been an outstanding issue for something like two years. I congratulate Senator Macdonald on finally asking it. That is a pretty slow reaction time. The situation in the port of Cairns is unsatisfactory and it has to be resolved. The situation was brought about by the collapse of the stevedoring company, the John Burke Group, in Cairns some two years ago and that, I think, was as a result of some decisions taken by the then Bjelke-Petersen State Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The port of Cairns has a long history, as I am sure the honourable senator would know, of port operations. The Waterside Workers Federation has had nearly a century of existence in the port of Cairns-a very long history of workers in that port which in its heyday employed some hundreds of waterside workers. It is entirely inappropriate for the Cairns Port Authority to determine what the union coverage for the port of Cairns shall be. That is a matter for the unions involved and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is up to the Cairns Port Authority to make the commercial operations of the Port of Cairns more efficient.

To that end, I have met with the new members of the Cairns Port Authority. I must say that they bring a refreshing new approach to the situation at the port of Cairns than the old Board had which, I might add, will greatly assist in the expedition of the solution to the port of Cairns. The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, at my request, following the agreement of the Cairns Port Authority, is convening a meeting in Cairns on the 23rd and 24th of this month and the issue in the port of Cairns will be resolved at that meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the open?
—No, we are going to sit in a room somewhere.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Powell asked me about a report carried in the August edition of Air International claiming that Chile was negotiating with Pakistan to purchase 10 of the Mirage aircraft which Australia had sold to Pakistan. Under the terms of the contract between Australia and Pakistan covering the sale of the aircraft, Pakistan undertook not to dispose of the aircraft or spares without the written consent of Australia and there has been a certificate provided to that effect. Clearly, in the experience of the Board it is still a problem and I urge the Government to look, once again, at providing proper resources to the ageing veterans who are advocates and to the organisations which have ageing membership, who are expecting to continue to do the job that they did when they were young on behalf of their comrades and their comrades' widows. It is important that we improve the resources available in that area.

I also want to draw the attention of the Senate to the decreasing military knowledge on the Veterans' Review Board. We are now facing the situation in which civilians are hearing cases on which they have no background expertise. Certainly there are doctors, but they are not doctors who have any military experience themselves and, in many cases, they have not had any detailed experience of treating servicemen or returned servicemen. It is very important, wherever it is possible, to get members on the Veterans' Review Board who have themselves had military experience. One deficiency that has been pointed out to me is that people who lack air crew experience hear claims made by former members of the Royal Australian Air Force. That is something which, in all humanity, should be rectified.

There also is clearly a need for very careful choice of personnel. In too many cases I hear claims of excessive legalism in a system which was designed to be outside the court system. I urge the Government to be exceedingly careful in appointing people to this Board, because often there is very real resentment of the system and the Government by veterans who have served their country and expect, in their old age, at least to get a fair deal when finally they come to the repatriation system for assistance.

I notice also that the cost per case has gone up quite dramatically this year-by something in the region of 30 per cent. I question why should this be so. The system has had a thorough going-over to try to do it as efficiently as possible, and still we find that the cost per case has gone from $711 last year to $918 this year. It seems an unsatisfactory jump in costs and I question why this is so.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphries) said, in his response, that he supported this recommendation, but when it came to taws he went to the Attorney-General who said he did not support it. I ask: Why is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs so low in the pecking order that his responsibility to the veterans in this country is as nothing in the face of lack of support from the Attorney-General? Can he not go and find powerful patrons, as seems to be the situation in the current Government? What will the Government do about this matter?

This report is entitled Government Funding of Academic and Related Research in Australia. It is a report of the Australian Science and Technology Council to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It presents statistics on government expenditure on academic and academically related research in Australia for the period 1984-87. In doing that, it compares that expenditure with spending in several European countries, notably the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, France, the Netherlands, the United States of America and Japan.

This is a very significant report in the sense that it looks at government expenditure over the early years of the Hawke Administration and compares that with expenditure by other technically advanced and industrialised countries. It says something that we all knew in this place but I think is worth underscoring. It states:

In conclusion, whichever means are used of allowing for variation in country size, government spending on academic and related research in Australia emerges as rather low in international terms, particularly relative to the continental European countries.

The report then goes on to look at overall expenditure. In terms of overall expenditure-government expenditure in addition to expenditure by private industry-Australia comes out very poorly indeed. On page 53 of the report it is stated:
In fact, in 1987 Australian GERD-
that is, gross expenditure on research and development-
at 1.24% of GDP was substantially lower than the other countries, which ranged from around 2.32% for the Netherlands-
almost twice as much-
to over 2.7%-
considerably more than twice as much-
for the Federal Republic of Germany, US and Japan.

The Government since that time has been progressively attempting to encourage more private investment in research in this country. That is having several quite disastrous consequences for research in that in this country we have among the industrial giants many multinational companies that carry out research overseas, and the Government is simply running down its input into research without a reasonable expectation that private industry will pick it up.

The other point that I think needs to be stressed is that as long as this sort of effort goes on it has to be recognised that in a country in which interest rates are very high it is extremely unlikely that private industry will participate in that sort of long term research which in the longer term will be of supreme benefit-the more important parts of research which need to go on.

Australia's effort in fundamental research has been quite good, and this report points out that our expenditure on environmental research is the best of all the countries in the comparison. That should be welcomed and emphasised. We spend $US4.3 per head on environmental research compared with the next highest country, the United States of America, at only $US3.5 per head, and Japan at only $US1.1 per head, so we are doing very well in that area.

Nonetheless, the amount of effort going into fundamental research which in the longer term will address both the environmental problems and the long term industrial and economic problems which this country faces is likely to be jeopardised by the practices of this Government, and this report underscores the likely failure of the Government's present practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to outline a case of an innocent illegal immigrant that I think is of particular importance and something that worries me greatly. It concerns the case of a young man called Boris Yip. Boris migrated to this country illegally with his parents some nine or 10 years ago. At the time Boris was a young boy in primary school. Boris lived those nine or 10 years in this country growing up as an Australian. In fact if one talks to Boris one will notice that he thinks and talks like an Australian and his heart is here in this country. Yet, earlier this year, Boris was forced to leave this country by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs which said that Boris was an illegal immigrant and, in spite of the fact that he did not come here of his own free will, he should nonetheless be forced to leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me highlight the fact that all the time that Boris was at school in Queensland he underwent private education at his parents' own funding. He received the highest tertiary entrance score it is possible to receive in Queensland, a tertiary entrance score of 990. He subsequently went on to do part-time university studies at the Queensland University of Technology. Here the problem arises, because although Boris was studying part time and getting exceptional results, and in spite of the fact that Boris was working at the age of 19 as an assistant contract manager for a very large construction company in Queensland, the Immigration Department believed that Boris was not the sort of person that we want in this country and it required him to leave.

One might think that is where the matter ends but, unfortunately, that is where the matter just starts. The Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations in its hearings earlier on this year heard that had Boris been picked up after the date on which he was, he in fact would not have been required to leave the country at all, because the Department has changed its guidelines. So one might think that that would entitle Boris to come back. But no, in fact the Department's treatment of this matter continues.

The Committee, I understand, requested the production of Boris's file at the Department of Immigration. For that purpose, I contacted Boris and got him to provide to me a letter authorising me to request production of his departmental file to any person for any purpose, and Boris signed that letter and sent it to me. I forwarded that letter on and it was received by the Joint Parliamentary Committee. One would have thought that after all of that the Department would have come clean and produced his file. But it did not. In fact I understand the file is still outstanding. I am told that what happened was that the Department wrote to the Ombudsman and said it had produced a file to the Committee. Yet, just yesterday, I received a letter by facsimile from a departmental officer saying that it was not possible to produce the file because certain parts of the file related to his brother and sister and his parents, and that those parts of the file could not be produced without their consent. That consent is now being made available to me, and in due course I will make that available both to the Committee and to the Department.

But the question has to be asked, why did the Department, as I am told, say to the Ombudsman that it had made the file available when the file was still in fact in the Department's possession? I believe that this matter requires further investigation. What also requires further investigation is what I think may be a case of victimisation by the Department against Boris Yip. The Department has sent a letter to Boris saying that he is required to pay $13,000 before he will be allowed to apply to come into this country again.

Where does this $13,000 come from? Well, $10,000 is supposedly the cost of Boris's university education in spite of the fact that he grew up in this country for nine or 10 years, and even under the strictest recommendation made by any member of that Committee Boris would have been allowed to stay and in fact would have been given permanent residence. But there is another $3,000 that the Immigration Department wants from Boris before he is even allowed to apply to come into the country again. That in fact relates to the education of his brother and sisters.

I believe that that is wholly unsatisfactory. It is administratively unsound and begs the possibility of some sort of victimisation by the Department of Boris Yip. I am not soft on illegal immigrants. We must make that point very clearly. Australia has a sovereign right to determine who comes into this country and who does not. But we also have to have some sense of compassion and every single requirement laid down by every member of that Committee would justify Boris being allowed to stay in this country.

Instead, he was deported to Hong Kong. He lost his job in this country-he was progressing in an incredible fashion for a person his age-he lost his university place and will have to start a course all over again, he has lost the country where he grew up, the country that he feels a part of, and this is all because of the attitude of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The really shameful thing about it is this: Boris's younger brother, who was born in this country prior to 1986, is still here. He is a minor, being looked after by friends. He is still here and he is an Australian citizen. But Boris, the elder brother, is not allowed to stay in the country to look after his younger sibling. That, I think, shows the incredible absurdity of the attitude of the Department to this particular case.

I would just like to highlight here and now the importance of compassionate conduct by the Department; the importance of fairness in dealing with people instead of treating them like animals; and the importance of giving Boris Yip a chance to come back to the country that he feels he belongs to, that I feel he belongs to, to come back to the country that I believe he would make a great citizen of. Boris Yip grew up as a fine Australian. Boris Yip will be a fine Australian. Boris Yip will always remain a fine Australian in spite of whatever the Immigration Department might try to do to keep him out of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon adjournment, we were discussing this particular amendment which seeks to impose a 60 per cent marginal income tax rate on that amount of income which is above $100,000. I wish to advert particularly to the remarks made by Senator Campbell. I must say that I found the picture of a society that he was painting somewhat nauseating. It was a combination of a free-for-all for the rich and powerful and charity crumbs for the rest. He was not ashamed to use the word `charity' and he linked it to two groups of people which I did not mention but which, in his perception, the people who were listening to the broadcasting of this Parliament would somehow find obnoxious, and that is lone parents and people in the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to remind the Opposition and in particular Senator Campbell once again that a society, a community, is judged by the way in which it treats its most disadvantaged members. I wonder whether the honourable senator heard the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, recently in a speech in Darwin detailing the severe disadvantages that the Aboriginal community still suffers. After 200 years of dispossession and deprivation, we still have not managed to make Aboriginal people full and equal members of our society who can enjoy the privileges and the services that we take as a matter of course. I think Senator Campbell's perception of this situation, as throwing charity crumbs to the poor, indicates the lack of vision, the lack of responsibility and the lack of the concept of development which, rather than charity, is underpinning the Australian Democrats' concept of social justice.

I refer once again to our alternative Budget. First of all, let me explain that the strategy of the Budget does not simply consist of a wish list. Yes, we do have $4 billion worth of expenditure items which go towards urgently needed community services. We also have, though, $7 billion of revenue items which create a $3 billion surplus which is in addition to the one achieved by the Treasurer and which would have much earlier than is now happening reduced our interest rates and reduced our dollar to help our primary producers and to help industry and prevent the sort of slide into unemployment that we are now having.

In addition to that, our concept is one of development-not only of human development but of development of the economy towards a sustainable society. I will just mention some of the items which would be financed in part out of that 60 per cent marginal income tax rate which, as I have said before, would yield $600m. There is risk sharing support for industry, with particular emphasis on export industries, of approximately $50m. There is research and development, mainly for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), of $100m. There are education initiatives, with strong emphasis on trade training, of $477m. There is international aid of $430m to underpin our global aspect of development. There is a savings incentive providing a rebate of 39 per cent on the first $1,000 interest, which would cost approximately $600m. That in itself could be paid out of that 60 per cent marginal income tax rate.

I wish Senator Campbell and the others on his side would take a look at how we view redistribution, that it is a strategic matter increasing the capacity of people and of business to create a stronger Australia and to create individuals who can master their lives so we can move together towards a more just and sustain- able society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity of responding to the Australian Democrats on the question of the power of the upper House in relation to increasing the burden of taxation. I wish to remind the Senate that the proposed amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990, Schedule 1 of the Bill, by clause 3 of the Bill, will amend the tables in parts I and XI of Schedule 7 of the Income Tax Act 1986. These refer to rates of tax on certain amounts of taxable income.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I think has completely escaped participants in the debate does not surround the word `imposing', although I will come back to that later in terms of the High Court's modern interpretation of giving the widest scope possible to words, but the third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution states, in part:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden-
that is the word, `burden'-
on the people.

The proposed amendment to the schedules, putting a rate of 60 per cent onto taxable income exceeding $100,000-in the words of the amendment-therefore would be deemed to infringe section 53 if proposed in the manner in which it was done in the Committee. The Committee may be able to request the lower House to make such an amendment, but it was not in that form when it was presented to the Committee this morning.

I remind the Committee that Bills imposing tax and fixing the rate of tax are separate because of section 55 of the Constitution which provides that `laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect'. Surprisingly, I feel that at this point the Government's argument is on this proposal of imposing a tax, because there is some doubt about that-I concede that-according to past interpretations.

One looks at the High Court's interpretation of current taxation legislation, which gives the widest possible scope of meaning to words, as it has done in terms of its interpretation of capital gains taxation. It gives the full intent of the Parliament or the Constitution to these words. But the argument, I submit, need not be on the more difficult point that I am suggesting could be addressed by the High Court in terms of the meaning and scope of the word `imposing' basically on section 53 because, essentially, it increases a burden on the people.

I believe that this matter, which is obviously of considerable interest, ought to be debated around academia for quite some time. But it is an issue that I think the Committee should come to grips with, particularly in light of the fact that the Government does not have a majority, and that we could see a repetition of such Bills. In the interests of clarity I would welcome a paper on this. I certainly intend to pursue the matter further because I think it is of interest to not only this chamber but also constitutional lawyers and certainly academia. I hope this might close the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you may be overconfident, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually support Senator Watson for the first time in this debate in his suggestion that we have this matter clarified. I am advised that his argument does not apply in a case where a rate of a burden that is already imposed is altered. But I agree that the wording of the Constitution leaves some doubt on that point. I would be perfectly happy to have the matter further qualified.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I might say that in terms of the present debate this is somewhat of a red herring because it does not address the substance of what has been put forward and the argument still stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — I go back to the substance of the argument which was being debated before lunch when the Opposition in particular attempted to beat the Australian Democrats about the ears because we chose to attempt to impose an increase in the taxation to the extent of a 60 per cent marginal rate on those with incomes over $100,000 per year. As Senator Spindler has pointed out, that involves some one half of one per cent of the Australian population, and would raise about $600m indicating, of course, the extent of the skewing in incomes among Australians-a point which has been made several times by both Senator Spindler and Senator Powell in calling for an inquiry into wealth distribution in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: What we heard repeatedly before lunch from many members of the Opposition was really an argument for financial elitism. They were arguing that those who had high incomes were indeed in some sense those in the community to whom one had to look up to. One had to offer them even greater incentives-using the Opposition's term. One had to hold out before them greater incentives so that somehow or other they would get the economy going.

Of course, this is precisely the part of the economic pattern which the Hawke Government has been pursuing. There has been increasing inequity in this country since 1983. There has been a wider distribution of incomes and that is indicated by the sharper rate of skewing in income distribution. The hope that the greater income and wealth flowing to the already wealthy would somehow lead to more investment in productive enterprises has simply not occurred. That wealth has been used predominantly, as we have seen, to speculate in paper shuffling.

In recent weeks we have seen some spectacular crashes among those who have been the paragons, presumably, of the Opposition. Indeed one of them was for a time the President of the Liberal Party and recently lost, in a spectacular fashion, large amounts of money. I for one see many other people in the community whom we should look up to. We should not use as a criterion of excellence a criterion of a need for support, a criterion for the need for incentive, those who have already, and often by rather dubious means, made large amounts of money.

Senator Short said that somehow we needed to make the cake grow so that out of a bigger cake we could more equitably share that cake and address the problems of social welfare and justice and also the environmental problems which beset us. Senator Short specifically attacked several speeches which I have made in recent days calling for a sustainable economy, an economy which will not grow in those terms used specifically by economists, which seems to be something that the Opposition does not understand. By growth, economists mean growth of gross national product in constant dollars-that is, taking out the inflation factor. Apparently, they do not understand that included in gross national product are all those expenses which are borne by a community to avoid the inevitable environmental health and other consequences of the growth which has been pursued. As we spend more out of our income on cleaning up the environment, as we spend more on the provision of social services to benefit those who are being left behind by this scramble for growth, those amounts do not appear on the debit side of gross national product. Those amounts are entered into gross national product as an addition.

Of course, one can have a growing economy. I point out to the Opposition that throughout most years recently the economy has been growing. But I think it is self-evident that, even with a growing economy, the majority of people have started to become worse off, so that even while the cake has been growing, we have started to become worse off. I think the empirical evidence simply shows that Senator Short really does not know what he is talking about.

I come back to the point that I made in opening. The Opposition, as I said, is holding up for veneration those who have made a large amount of money in saying that our tax structure needs to provide more incentive to those who have already made more than $100,000. Senator Panizza said they are the people who are risking their capital. There are a large number of people in our community who are risking a great deal more than their capital-people on low incomes who are going out after social goals from a very poor base indeed. I can tell this Committee, from my work over many years in the environment movement, that many of those people are living on the dole or on very poor incomes but they regard the protection and their work for the environment as far more important than going out and making more dollars.

Those people risk a great deal and are contributing an enormous amount to the long term welfare of the Australian community. There are people who work in the social welfare area on little or no incomes because they believe that social justice is very important. They risk a great deal, and I find it quite reprehensible that the Opposition holds up risk of capital as the criterion by which people should be judged as worthy of more incentive. I thank the Opposition for taking that line because it clearly delineates between those who hold up greed as the incentive which needs to drive our society and those, certainly on the Democrats benches, who hold up social justice and equity as the criteria which should guide us.

Finally, I would point out to the Opposition that it is a matter of record that as inequity increases-and inequity has been increasing in Australian society for quite some time-so do a lot of the other concomitants of that inequity. Crime, for instance, increases, as do the problems of ill health and drugs. Therefore, the costs on the community as a consequence of that inequity also increase.

I put to members of the Opposition that even out of self-interest it is better for them to support a greater degree of equity and fairness in a society than simply pursue the increasing divergence of incomes and wealth in the Australian community. Eventually that increasing disparity in wealth and income will be borne home on them in inability to live safely, to live securely, and to live in a healthy and desirable environment. The amendment moved by my colleague Senator Spindler deserves the strong endorsement of this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the Australian Democrats may not want to hear this contribution, but unfortunately it is inevitable. At least I will keep it brief.

SPEECH.PARA: I first refer to the very important constitutional points raised by Senator Watson. I acknowledge their importance, even though they are not important with regard to any impending passage of this amendment; nevertheless, they are issues of substance. I have asked for a paper to be prepared by the Clerks for distribution to all senators on this important question. That may fuel further discussion, or it may be such a comprehensive paper that it concludes the discussion. Senator Watson has raised an issue of importance which requires serious consideration. I have asked for something to at least commence that discussion and we will see where it goes from there. I thank him for raising the matter.

I return to my fundamental point on behalf of the Government with regard to this amendment, which goes back to the response I gave in regard to amendments Nos 2 and 3. The Government will not agree to the Senate, rather than the Government, setting the tax rates in the Budget.

I make only two other brief comments. One is that tax rates are not only distributional issues. They also have fundamental macro-economic consequences and, therefore, the Government will reserve its right to set macro-economic policy, and I believe it must.

I make one point about the progressivity of the tax system. Although the top rate is a factor in that, one of the things that is too often neglected is that the spread of tax rates is not significantly different now from that which it was when the 60c rate was the top rate because then the lowest rate was 30c. We have now a spread from 47c to 21c. So the progressivity in terms of the relationship between the rate paid by low income earners and that paid by high income earners has barely changed. In one statistical sense one could say that it has expanded, but in literal terms of the number of percentage points in the spread it is essentially the same as it has always been.

For those reasons we will not be supporting the amendment. There were a certain number of things said in opposition to the amendment which are not views that I share, but those views were entitled to be put and I listened to them with interest. I would refer Senator Campbell, in view of some of his remarks about the charity model of welfare distribution, to an answer given in the House of Representatives today by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on that issue which I thought summed it up-not exactly succinctly, but effectively. Therefore, for those reasons the Government will not be supporting this amendment.
