TALK.START.PARA: —The Arts, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 amends eight Acts; it is a compendium amendment. Three of these Acts relate to the area of my responsibility as shadow Minister for the arts, heritage, sport and youth affairs. They are the Australian Film, Television and Radio School Act 1973, the National Gallery Act 1975 and the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1976. Other matters, particularly tourism, covered by these amendments will be dealt with by my colleague and friend Senator Newman.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Opposition have basically no disagreement with the amendments, particularly following the Government's sensible decision to accept some of our recommendations about how these amendments could be improved. I appreciate the cooperation from the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Simmons, and his staff and officers of the Department in making these improvements to the Bill. It is a pleasant situation when one can, in fact, discuss these issues with officers of the Department and with the Minister in a friendly and cooperative way so that procedures of government go on in a coherent way without unnecessary confrontation.

It is worth noting that, despite impressions that one would gather from the media, the procedures of this place probably involve agreement about 90 per cent of the time in terms certainly of the thrust of legislation. This chamber is not a place of continual confrontation, but a place where senators seek to do what they believe is right and proper in, hopefully, a cooperative way so that we end up with the best result. In this case, I believe we are ending up with the best result.

The amendments to the Australian Film, Television and Radio School Act simply rectify a minor wording error that took place in last year's amendments. I do not want to go on too much about it, but it would be nice and more efficient if the Government could get its amendments right in the first place without having to bring in this kind of amendment; nonetheless, we certainly believe that the error should be corrected and corrected retrospectively, as this legislation does. Clearly the wording errors merit correction from the time the amending Act came in on 19 June last year.

The second Act in my area, the National Gallery Act, is being amended to introduce flexible, workable and responsible disposable mechanisms for works of art from the national collection in line with recommendations made in the review of the Australian National Gallery in July 1989. These involve removing the requirement that two independent experts be consulted, but leaving ministerial approval as mandatory and, I believe, leaving enough safeguards to ensure that there will not be wrongful disposal of works of art.

As I understand it, no works of art have yet been disposed of by the National Gallery. It has been totally acquisitive 100 per cent of the time, but there is a prospect that it may well run out of space or facilities as a result of its acquisition program, and there may well be judgments that some works do not justify their being held in a national collection.

One of the reasons for changing the system, which has never been used, was the requirement that a report was needed from two independent experts on the importance of the work of art to the national collection before it was disposed of, because it could well be that the fees paid for such advice could exceed the value of the work, especially if the only relevant expert happened to be overseas.

The Opposition feels convinced that the changes are appropriate, particularly now that the Government has accepted my request to it that any such disposal should be listed in the annual report of the Australian National Gallery to allow public scrutiny of the list. I thank the Government for its sensible decision to include that in the amendments that were made to this Bill in the House of Representatives.

One thing I would mention in this context is that the Government, in this instance, is implementing recommendations of the review of the Australian National Gallery by Mr Gerard Early. This report was presented in February 1989. It seems to me that it is a sensible and detailed report.
For that reason, the Opposition will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion along these lines:

At the end of the motion, add: ``but the Senate is of the opinion that in the absence of any public reasons to the contrary, the Government should implement the other major recommendation of the Early Report into the Australian National Gallery that its private sector fund-raising activities be transferred to the Australian National Gallery Foundation.

As I said, this is a fairly detailed and well argued report. I understand that there are pragmatic problems related to implementing the Early report. But I should say, without making too much of a pun, that not only has the Government failed to provide any sensible reasons for not proceeding with the recommendations but its response has been more late than early.

The response from the Australian National Gallery to this report of February 1989 is contained in a letter dated 13 September 1990. The letter from Mr Whitlam, the Chairman of the Council, comments on fund raising, which is the matter I refer to in my amendment. As I say, it is dated a year and a half after the report came out. Mr Whitlam says this:
Council has resolved that fund-raising activities, including sponsorship, should remain the responsibility of the Gallery and not the Foundation.
There is no rational explanation of why the Early proposals have been rejected.

This is a big ticket item which involves millions of dollars. It is recognised that the Australian National Gallery, being centred in what is relatively a small town, does not have the same sorts of immediate and ready access to those private sector people who may well wish to assist galleries that are closer and in larger centres where the offsetting public relations benefits might be more readily available to them.
What Mr Whitlam did say in his letter-and this obviously does give a clue to the pragmatic problems surrounding the Foundation-is this:
The Chairman and Executive Director of the Foundation have recently resigned.
He goes on:

Council is currently reviewing the structure of the Foundation and its Board of Directors. To date the Foundation has raised $3.07 million (including the Nomura scholarship). It is an important adjunct to the Gallery which must be supported and maintained.

I must say that I totally agree with that. But I am concerned that the Council has failed to explain why, when it is to be supported and maintained, it is not to be given the job which the Opposition believes is the most appropriate job, and that is taking over the private sector fund raising activities.

One of the reasons that the Foundation is in some difficulties in terms of staffing is that the Executive Director, Mrs Carol Haslem, has been very unwell. I am certain that all of us in this chamber would wish her a speedy recovery. She is, of course, well known to members of the Opposition in particular because her husband, John, was the member for the Australian Capital Territory in the late 1970s-and a very good member too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Watson for his endorsement of that point. The Chairman was Mr Rene Rivkin. He has also retired, I think not because of ill-health. Financial situations obviously have changed in the city of Sydney and perhaps Mr Rivkin is busy elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: But the fact that there is no chairman and executive director may be a temporary reason for not maintaining the Foundation as the appropriate body. But I should mention that quite shortly there is going to be a change in the position of chairman of the Council of the National Gallery itself. In other words, the absence of a chairman or the impending departure of a chairman does not necessarily render a body inanimate or incapable of working.

I should just say in passing, of course, that the question of who is going to become the new chairman of the Australian National Gallery is a matter of some public debate. I will come to that later. I want to mention the recommendations of the Early report which I believe should have been either implemented or dealt with in the correspondence from Mr Whitlam or in the Government's response to it. The report says:
The establishment of the Australian National Gallery Foundation in September 1987 was a major initiative which should significantly enhance the capacity of the Gallery for fund raising. . . .

Responsibility for fund raising on behalf of the ANG is currently split between the . . . Foundation (which seeks donations) and the Gallery itself (which seeks sponsorship). As both these activities require similar skills and coordination of effort, the sponsorship function should be transferred to the Foundation.

Despite the success of the ANG in raising off-budget revenue, it has not reached its maximum potential in this area given a rather uncoordinated approach and constraints created by the overall financial and staffing strictures on the Gallery.

The ANG's entrepreneurial activities (excluding entrance fees) would be better coordinated and be more effective if devolved to the Australian National Gallery Foundation under a licence arrangement. These changes would remove the funding of some ANG staff from the Federal budget and, by eliminating inappropriate constraints, help to maximise opportunities for off-budget revenue.

Separating the Gallery's fund raising and entrepreneurial activities from its core heritage functions would facilitate the focussing on the clear objective of maximising off-budget revenue. It would assist the establishment of funding targets and strategies to meet them. It would also impose a commercial test on decisions which are sometimes currently made on an ad hoc basis.
The report goes on:

Donations and business sponsorship are more likely to be received for specific projects than for recurrent general expenditure. Potential donors would be reluctant to donate if they believed their gifts would serve merely to relieve the Federal Government's financial responsibilities for the Gallery. Opportunities to raise off-budget revenue can be maximised therefore only against a secure base of Federal Government funding for the ANG's administrative and core heritage functions.
All revenues raised by the Australian National Gallery Foundation should be retained and used by the Foundation on behalf of the Gallery. There should be no reduction-
and I want to stress this-
in the Federal Parliamentary appropriation for the ANG as a result of successful revenue raising by the Australian National Gallery Foundation.

I want to stress that one of the key points of the Opposition policy for the arts is that one should not penalise success in arts areas by in fact automatically reducing government support for those organisations that have either proved themselves to be efficient or competent in the area of raising money. Unfortunately, far too often we find success being penalised and incompetence being rewarded by increased funding when there is pressure on government support for the arts.

Obviously the National Gallery Foundation needs to be considerably strengthened at the moment. In view of the fact that it has been some time since the Executive Director unfortunately suffered ill health, I think it is a matter for regret that measures have not yet apparently been taken to restore the strength of that organisation.

The Early report has been accepted pretty thoroughly in other areas. In fact, the letter from Mr Whitlam, the Chairman of the Australian National Gallery, outlines the places where that report has been put into effect by the Gallery. For example, he says:

The Gallery Council has reviewed the Acquisitions Policy and priorities for the National Collection. It has been agreed that emphasis should be placed on Australian art (including Aboriginal art) and the arts of Asia.
The letter goes on:

A successful major sponsorship was concluded recently with Nomura Securities, Tokyo, which donated $2 million for the construction of an Asian gallery. For the first time the Asian collection will now have a permanent space within the Gallery for display.``Nomura Court'' is expected to be completed in March 1991.
I am glad to see that he also responded to the Early report by saying:

While reviewing the Acquisitions Policy, Council reaffirmed its resolve to continue to maintain and develop a national collection of works of art across all geographic boundaries for the enjoyment, education and stimulation of all Australians. The finest Australian works in all media will be exhibited against the finest examples of Western art and other traditions.

Unfortunately, however, on the next matter, public access, there has been a glitch-not a glitch of the Gallery's making but a glitch relating to the structure in which it has to display its art. As Mr Whitlam says:

The Gallery has continued to develop its public access and promotional programs through its exhibitions drawn from the National Collection. The travelling exhibitions program has been expanded to include a minimum of three exhibitions each year to tour all states and territories.

He points out the success of the British Museum exhibition, which, when in Canberra, attracted 190,000 visitors. But here comes the problem: because of the requirement to spend $3.5m fixing the roof, the Australian National Gallery will not be able to have any blockbuster-I think that is the appropriate expression-exhibitions this year, such as the British Museum exhibition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might have brought in the money to pay for it.

—Yes, a blockbuster exhibition might well have brought in some money to help contribute to repairing the roof. The fact is that $3.5m is being spent on what is basically a pretty new building to replace, in effect, the real cover of that building. A new roof is being built over the existing roof because the existing roof is no good.

SPEECH.PARA: I look around the new buildings in Canberra and wonder what kind of design, construction and supervision went into them. So shortly after the National Gallery has opened, in relative terms, it has to have its roof replaced. Major government offices that have leaked at, I think, Belconnen have cost multimillions of dollars to fix. A major building in Civic had to be vacated, at enormous cost, by the Public Service. What on earth is happening to the standards of construction here, particularly in public buildings? When multimillions of dollars such as this are being wasted, there is some imperative to find out what on earth is going wrong. To my knowledge, that matter has not received any attention within the Parliament. I believe it should.

Another matter that Mr Whitlam raised was that the Gallery is investigating possibilities of high resolution new technology in relation to public access to imagery of works in the collection. A collection study room will shortly be available to students and researchers and members of the public on written request. A review of the Gallery library will take place in October this year-it is obviously taking place now-as part of the public access review.

Clearly, this report by Mr Early was of great merit. It should have been more seriously considered in respect of this vital question of raising money. The Opposition's clear policy on the arts is to encourage private sector support and funding. The solution Mr Early has recommended, whereby the funding by a foundation is separated from the body itself, will remove the reluctance of potential donors to donate so that they will not believe that their gifts will merely relieve the Federal Government of its financial responsibilities and that the Government will substitute private sector funding for government funding. The people who like to donate to these bodies like to feel not that they are letting the Government off the hook, but that they are doing something worth while.

I encourage the Government to steal another of our policies. After all, it steals most of them. It does not implement them too well, but it steals the policies. This might be an appropriate policy for the Government to steal because it would be to the benefit of the Australian National Gallery and to the benefit of the Australian people, particularly those who come to Canberra in their millions not only to look at the National Gallery but also to visit this Parliament.

I am also disappointed at the suggestion that someone for whom I have the highest regard-that is, Mr Lionel Bowen-is being widely tipped as the expected new Chairman of the Australian National Gallery. Mr Bowen, the former Deputy Prime Minister, is a highly qualified, competent, able and charming man who has qualifications for a great range of public positions. This is not one of them. As a retiring Council member, Mrs Seidler, said last week-this is quoted from the Sun-Herald of last Sunday:
The first necessary qualification for a council member-
that is, a member of the Council of the Australian National Gallery-
is a demonstrated knowledge of and commitment to art and art museums.

Mr Bowen has at no stage demonstrated that first necessary qualification. When I saw in the paper the other day that he was entering a beginner's course in art appreciation, I felt that I should commend him for his enthusiasm, but I regret that he feels that that will provide the necessary background to take on what should be one of the most significant roles in the Australian arts community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a snobbish comment.

—It is not snobbish; it is practical. It demonstrates the incompetence of this Government's approach that the Minister for Industrial Relations would interject in that way. If his view is that it does not matter a damn whether the person who is the Chairman of the Australian National Gallery has the first knowledge or touch of enthusiasm or interest in art, it demonstrates why the National Gallery has been having so much trouble with this Government. While we have an outstanding new Director and an outstanding new team at the National Gallery, if they are to be burdened with the lead weight of retired Labor politicians whose appointments are justified on the grounds that it does not matter whether people on the Council do not have any interest in art whatsoever, then the National Gallery will be in for a bad couple of years before we get into office and fix it up. I thank the Minister for interjecting in that way. I feel now confirmed in my view that this Government has an arrogant disregard for what is in the best interests of the Australian National Gallery. Turning to the next--
—You are a snob.

—I am prepared to give the Minister another serve any time he wants to interject. The next point I want to make concerns another element in the Bill before us which is of some moment, and that is an amendment to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act to overcome administrative difficulties which have arisen in the operation of the heritage export control scheme. The amendment will enable a principal public collecting institution, but not private collectors, to apply to the Minister for a general export permit and so avoid the present requirement of individual export permits whenever lending Australian material overseas, as long as it is for research, exhibition or a similar purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: Because these collections-that is, in principal public collecting institutes-are already controlled and protected by Acts of Commonwealth, State or Territory parliaments, the administrative cost and inconvenience of individual permits is considered unnecessary. The amendments will also exempt from the Acts all cultural heritage objects temporarily imported into Australia under a loan agreement from foreign governments or collecting institutions.

As a result of my representations to the Government, it is agreed that the Act is now to be further amended-and, in fact, was in the lower House-to exempt private overseas collections on loan to Australian exhibitors because, clearly, not only was it unfair but it also imposed an unreasonable burden on the Minister in the event that such a private collection coming here could have been subject to court action by some other body or country, which may have claimed that the collection or the works of art may have been improperly obtained.

For example, there could be some disagreement with the Greek Government if the Elgin marbles came to Australia. This arrangement will now protect those bodies. I put this view to the Government after discussing it with various State gallery directors, and I am grateful to the Minister for his sensible recognition of the need to cooperate and end up with the best possible result. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that in the absence of any public reasons to the contrary, the Government should implement the other major recommendation of the Early Report into the Australian National Gallery that its private sector fund-raising activities be transferred to the Australian National Gallery Foundation''.

As I said, that is strictly in line with Opposition policy. It is strictly in line with good sense. It is strictly in line, I believe, with giving the Australian National Gallery the maximum opportunity to raise as much funding as possible from the private sector without damaging its capacity quite properly to seek funding from the public sector. In all other respects we totally support the amendments affecting three of the eight Acts now being amended, and my colleague Senator Newman will deal with other sections of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to part 4 of the Arts, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. Part 4 deals with the change in the size of the Australian Tourist Commission Board by an increase of one member. The Opposition does not, in fact, oppose this measure although we are critical of the Government that it should be necessary. We believe that the problem is not currently with the numbers who are on the Board, but with the composition and that, of course, lies within the Government's prerogative.

SPEECH.PARA: In his second reading speech the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) said:

Amendments . . . will allow for the addition of one extra member to the Board of Directors of the Australian Tourist Commission, which will make it possible for a more broadly-based representation of persons with relevant skills, experience and background to be on the Board.

There, in a nutshell, is an admission of failure by the Government that the appointments which it has made to the board have not provided that necessary broadly-based representation of persons with relevant skills, experience and background. If the Government does not have the people on the board that it needs, then whose fault is that? People do not self-nominate; people are appointed by the Government.

However, we agree with the intent of the Minister. We do believe that that is exactly who should be on the board. We feel it is the Government's failure that the board does not currently have that representation. I do not wish to be offensive and to canvass individuals on this, but it is the appointments which have already been made and those which have been made in the past of people who have now left the board that we criticise. We do need a mixture of experience and new blood at regular intervals on the board.

We face, within a short period of time, changes to Qantas Airways Ltd which will make it yet another airline operating in the commercial sector. One would query whether Qantas, for example, has a God given right to permanent representation on the board. If other Australian airlines are interested in bringing tourists to this country and have expertise in the tourist industry, surely it should be envisaged that there could be a rotation of representation from the airline industry.

We do not need people appointed to the board primarily because of their friendships in high places. We need commercial expertise and we need a proven track record in either the tourist industry or marketing. For example, we do not need a special environmental expert on the board. We question why the Government has seen fit to provide such a limited area of expertise as a permanent board position. Important though the cross-flow of information that may come from such a member may be to the board of the Australian Tourist Commission-and I acknowledge the impact of tourism on the environment, and the importance of the environment to tourism-it is surely unnecessary to provide special affirmative action, if you like, for the environmental community on the board of the Australian Tourist Commission. The Government can obtain the information that is needed for the board from its own resources, from its own environmental department.

This is a vital industry to our economy. I do not think there would be a member or senator in this Parliament who would not recognise its vital importance. It has never been more important than it is now. I and my family have been in the tourist industry for a number of years now. I suppose, therefore, we have a greater interest than many in how well this industry progresses, but it is not just a personal involvement that makes me concerned to see that this industry is well operated.

It is absolutely critical for our economy that our export income is increased and if ever there was an industry which gives us enormous potential for increasing our export income it is tourism. We are looking at something like $6.5 billion in income from tourism. It is the biggest hard currency earner that this country has. It employs half a million people now-and that makes it the biggest private sector employee-but it has enormous potential to increase employment in this industry and to increase export earnings for this country, yet the Government's investment is only $40m.

Forty million dollars is a large amount of money in the average person's calculation, but how much did we give to Kodak to keep it from leaving the electorate of Wills? When governments talk money, it is big money, and $40m for government tends to be but a spit in the bucket.

That $40m, I remind the Senate, must be placed in the context of an industry which is struggling to recover after probably one of the most devastating blows that any industry could have suffered. I refer, of course, to the airline dispute which decimated the tourist industry and which sent many entrepreneurs broke. It will be some years yet, I think, before we see the final wash-up of the effect on the tourist industry in Australia of that devastating strike. It has not only done long term damage to the individuals in the industry now, but also it has affected our reputation overseas.

Only last week on my return from the visit by the parliamentary delegation to the Soviet Union, I stopped overnight in Singapore, and I was appalled to find how many people talked to me about our bad record in strikes. Taxi drivers would say, `It's not much use going out to meet Qantas when it is supposed to be scheduled. You never know when they will get here because there will be strikes back home in Australia'.

We talked to people in the tourist industry, who said that people do not want to travel on to Australia; they do not like to think they will be marooned when they get here. And here we go with yet another fuel strike that is likely to affect the confidence in our industry, even if it does not directly affect the industry physically. The long term effects of our reputation of bad industrial relations has enormous ramifications for the tourist industry.

Another area in which I would like the Government to make a greater commitment concerns the opening of our airports to more carriers and more foreign flights; in other words, opening up our skies. We have but one service a week to Korea, yet I believe that we could multiply that six or seven times with the volume of business that is going backwards and forwards between the two countries, usually on somebody else's airline. There is the Soviet Union. There is an enormous opportunity to provide for direct Moscow to Australia flights.

We have the nonsense and the long delays in trying to negotiate deals with Taiwan; and Lauda Air in Vienna, a vigorous company, is trying to provide more direct flights to Australia. The airlines in those countries, if encouraged, if given an open skies treatment, would bring travellers to this country. It is in their interests as entrepreneurs to keep their aircraft filled and to sell Australia for us. If we were smart, if we were truly the clever country, that is the way we would be thinking, instead of engaging in these miserly, mean-spirited negotiations and the haggling that goes on year after year-`You give me a bit of this and I will give you a bit of that'. It is no way to expand an industry that is so important to us all.

There is a great impression in Europe that Australia is a long way away. People will travel from Europe as far as India. They might even get as far as Thailand or Singapore, but the extra distance on to Australia seems to make us geographically impossible. We have to be able to make it easy, quick, trouble-free and direct to get here. We have to improve our record in industrial relations so that people will feel that if they come this far they will be able to get home again; there will be reliable travel. It has to be easy so that they can come all the way with one airline, from wherever their home might be. If we opened up our skies these things would make it possible for foreign travellers to come here in greater numbers.

As I have said, it is absolutely vital for our future as well as for the industry that we increase our visitor numbers to this country. It is clearly an industry of entrepreneurs, people willing to have a go, people of energy and vitality, and people often flying by the seat of their pants because their ideas are bigger than their capital and their bank balances.

On the whole these are not people with their hands out looking for protection. They are pretty much vigorous independents who want less government regulation and less interference by government. But they do want to see first-rate people appointed to the Australian Tourist Commission. They want to have confidence that where government of any type is involved in the tourist industry it understands the ethos and the needs of the industry and has no passengers on government instrumentalities.

There are some good people on the Board of the Commission now, but what is needed is a board that is totally committed to the industry, packed with marketing skills and with proven expertise in business. There is no room for tokenism of any kind on the Board. If the Government had always in the past appointed people with the necessary backgrounds and skills there would not have been any need to expand the Board as we are being asked to do now. One additional position on this Board is not the answer, but the Opposition will not oppose the Government's amendment to the Australian Tourist Commission Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 proposes a number of important changes to the Child Care Act 1972, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953. I will confine my remarks to the health related aspects of the Bill, whilst my colleague Senator Alston will address the proposed changes to the Child Care Act. Whilst not opposing this Bill, on behalf of the Opposition I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) calls on the Government to allow patients to insure against the `gap' which is the difference between the scheduled medical fee and the Medicare benefit;

(b) condemns the Government for providing automatic CPI increases to the maximum patient contribution which will remove the opportunity for public and parliamentary scrutiny and debate of these increases;
(c) calls on the Government to implement an education program on its minimum pricing policy and on the use of generic drugs;
(d) condemns the Government for abolishing Medicare cover for those medical expenses incurred by Australians while travelling overseas;

(e) condemns the Government for its attempt to usurp free market forces by establishing the Pharmaceutical Restructuring Authority to make recommendations on applications for new pharmacies, and on the amalgamation and closure of other pharmacies''.

The Bill seeks to widen the maximum gap between the Medicare benefit and the schedule fee from $20 to $26. This is an overnight jump of 30 per cent-not too harsh, some might say, considering there has been no increase since 1986, but in 1986 the gap widened from $10 to $20. So in less than five years we have seen a 160 per cent increase in the size of the gap. As usual, this indexation infatuated Government initially hits us with a hike that is many times the consumer price index (CPI) and then has the gall to legislate so that all further increases in the fee gap and the safety net will be indexed to inflation. The Government will benefit to the tune of $11m annually from this proposal. The taxpayer must bear the cost because this Government stubbornly denies it the right to insure against this ever widening gap.

This Bill will maintain the unfair situation whereby Australians have to pay a 1 1/4 per cent Medicare levy and, if patients want to avoid the long hospital queues and not be subjected to waiting for what is euphemistically called elective surgery, they have to insure themselves privately and also have to pay the gap. This was brought home to me only this year when I had a condition that, had I not had private health insurance, would have been considered elective surgery. I had to have a cartilage removed and I would have joined those hospital queues. Fortunately, I am one of the few people left who have private medical insurance but I had to pay for the gap. What will be the result of a continuation of this triple whammy to which many Australians are subjected? It will continue the acceleration of the flight from private health insurance schemes that has been going on since this Government has been in power and that will be coupled with the ever increasing hospital queues.

In his second reading speech in the other place, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) announced that the minimum pricing policy will commence on 1 December 1990. This policy is estimated to net the Government $16m in 1991 and $47m annually thereafter. Whilst recognising that this policy will result in significant cost benefits for the Government, I have my doubts whether the Minister has given sufficient thought to how this change will affect doctors, pharmacists and patients. Despite Minister Staples' promise that he would provide the shadow Minister, Dr Bob Woods, with lists of the present and planned education programs relating to the minimum pricing policy, I am informed by his office that to date these lists have not been forthcoming.

Consequently, in my opinion, the Government has failed to demonstrate that it has any comprehensive plan for the implementation of this policy-a comprehensive plan that would educate doctors, allay the fears of patients, and minimise the financial costs borne by pharmacists. Within six weeks-I remind honourable senators that this is to be introduced within six weeks-the Government thinks it can educate the medical profession to prescribe cheaper alternatives in every case. Patients will have to be weaned off their familiar brand name drugs, which some have been taking for many years. Come 1 December, the beleaguered pharmacist will have to cope with yet another Government enforced change.

If this yet to be sighted Government education campaign fails to be 100 per cent effective, who will suffer? If in six weeks the Government cannot educate the doctors and cannot allay the fears of patients who will suffer? It will be either the patient, who has to pay the difference between the drug that has been prescribed by the doctor and the generic drug, or the pharmacist who must explain the system to the patient, get the prescription amended by the doctor and convince the patient of the efficacy of the unfamiliar drug. Here we have another task the pharmacist has to do. The patient who comes in, who has been used to getting a particular drug, is now not able to get it or has to pay the extra; or the pharmacist has to spend time explaining to the patient that he will have to ring the doctor and that the patient will have to deal with a new drug.

Section 103 of the National Health Act prevents pharmacists from substituting the cheaper generic drug. They must get the doctor's prior approval before dispensing the generic alternative. For various reasons, the doctor might not be available when the patient comes into the pharm- acy. The patient may come in after the doctor has left his surgery. This means that sick patients will be kept waiting until the doctor can return the pharmacist's call or the pharmacist can get in touch with the doctor.

I wonder whether Minister Staples has a skerrick of pragmatism in his bones, having regard to the way he has introduced many of these changes to this and other community services and health Acts without thinking those changes through. In practical terms, this hastily implemented change has the potential to inflict mayhem in pharmacies, especially when two or more patients who have different doctors and who require changes to their prescriptions enter a pharmacy one after the other or at the same time. The pharmacist has to try to deal with a patient who is sick, and that is why the person is there. The patient either has to wait until the pharmacist gets approval from the doctor or the pharmacist will have to tell the patient to return at some later stage. Some pharmacists, in their generosity, have the drugs delivered, especially to elderly patients. This is of no benefit to the pharmacist, except that he is delivering a service.

All in all, I believe it will be quite messy. For this thankless task, what is being bandied around? A $2 compensatory payment for the pharmacist who may in fact make two or three phone calls to the doctor, who has to spend time with the patient explaining the changes, and who may even end up, because he is concerned about the patient, delivering the drug to the patient, especially if the patient is old. As we all know, about 80 per cent of people who have pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) drugs are over 65.

This looks like another of this Minister's hastily conceived and poorly thought through policy initiatives. Not as hastily conceived but as poorly thought through is the Government's latest attempt to ostracise from Medicare those Australians who are temporarily overseas. Ever since the inception of Medicare in 1984, one has been able to claim for medical services whilst temporarily overseas. Honourable senators in this chamber will remember in 1988 the toing-and-froing of an amendment when the Government was thwarted in its attempt to try the very same thing. When it came back to the chamber, having gone from the Senate back to the House of Representatives and back to the Senate again, the Government said words to the effect, `The reason we are taking away the Medicare benefits of people overseas is because people are very confused about whether they are entitled to Medicare benefits when they are overseas. We will help them. This nanny government will help them by letting them know that they have no entitlements because we will take them away. If they do not know what their rights are, the easiest way to deal with that is to take those rights away'.

That is what the Government plans to do in this Bill. It is doing exactly what it said then and is giving similar reasons: people are not aware of their entitlements so they should not be covered by Medicare at all. Many members of the general public who are travelling will find it most interesting that they are still required to pay 1 1/4 per cent of their salary by way of Medicare levy and will not get back any benefits. But this time the Minister did not give a very good explanation in his rushed second reading speech.

The people to whom this Bill refers are those who are continuing to pay their taxes, including their Medicare levy, in Australia. They are being told that they cannot claim a rebate for medical expenses incurred while temporarily overseas. Who does this discriminate against? It discriminates against those whose work entails them being called overseas. It discriminates against those who are negotiating the all-important export contracts that are needed to save us from the Argentinean road. Let me give an example. Only last Saturday, I think, a group of 11 women from Western Australia called L'Entrepreneuse went to Indonesia to negotiate export deals for small businesses, particularly small businesses run by women. In future, if those women get sick in Indonesia they will not be entitled to any benefits. But the Government does not worry about them.

The Bill discriminates against those who carry the Australian flag overseas: our entertainers and our sports people, many of whom are young-especially our sports people-and living on the smell of an oil rag to achieve excellence and to represent our country. They will be denied Medicare benefits. They will pay their Medicare levy, but if they get sick while overseas they will not get any assistance from the Government.

The Bill also discriminates against academics. I mentioned in a speech when the issue was raised before that many academics borrow money to take study leave, to go overseas and get experience to bring back to Australia so they can contribute to research and teaching. Let me say that I have benefited on two occasions from study leave in the United States and, for a period, in Great Britain. Those people make enormous sacrifices, taking their families. If those people go overseas for 11 months they will pay $600 or $700 in Medicare levy, but they will get nothing in return, because the Government says that they are too stupid to know what entitlements they have. If they are in America they will have a bill as long as their arm. The Government says that it will help those people by taking away their Medicare benefits: they will be aware that because they do not have benefits they will take out private health insurance. I hope that the academics who have supported this Government realise how caring, how considerate, it is and how stupid it thinks the academics are for not knowing what their rights are.

The Bill also discriminates against humanitarian and voluntary workers, people in missionary organisations and those working for organisations such as Interserve, which I have had a lot to do with. Volunteer workers illustrate to the world the generosity and compassion possessed by the majority of Australians but, unfortunately, not by this Government. Those people working in some of the remote regions of the world will not be entitled to any Medicare benefits, despite the fact that they will be earning an Australian salary.

The Government claims that Medicare is a universal, comprehensive health insurance scheme. I tell you what, it is not universal for the people who will be travelling, as I said, representing Australia, working to get exports for Australia and learning in academic institutions and other organisations to bring back research and teaching skills. I hope the public realise what this Government is doing.

The restricting of Medicare benefits or rebates to services provided in Australia will save the Government $5m annually. This is petty cash compared with the wastefulness that this Government condones in a myriad of other areas. This change is unfair and uncalled for. Not only do I urge the Government to reconsider but also I remind it of its obligation to outline the reasons behind its decision, which discriminates against the very people that Australia should be encouraging.

The most important part of this Bill is the setting up of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority which will make recommendations relating to the initial approval of pharmacies, the payment of essential pharmacy allowances, and the closure and amalgamation of pharmacies. In the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority, the Government is admitting that its policy of over-regulation and constantly disrupting market forces in the pharmacy industry has driven pharmacists to the wall. By setting up this Authority, and at the same time virtually eradicating the independent Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, this Government has achieved its objective of becoming the puppeteer of pharmacists from when they set up until when they sell up.

For over half a century, market forces have provided us with an efficient and viable pharmaceutical dispensing industry. The public only have to tell us that. We only have to find out where pharmacists are on the social acceptability scale and look where politicians are to find out just what pharmacists do in our community.

Now that the intrusive tinkering of the Minister has nullified the effects of market forces, he is telling those pharmacists who have survived the battering that they must finance those who have been less fortunate or those who have been downright inefficient. It is a strange thing to have to do. If I were a pharmacist who had managed my business and had made a good choice about where to put my pharmacy, I could not understand having to subsidise those who were getting out of the pharmacy industry. Paying to do this? It is a bizarre concept.

This Authority will do precious little to improve the efficiency of the system. It will not mean the writing of fewer scripts overall. That problem has to be addressed in another area-medical education. When I look at the report of the Doherty Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce, I see that the Government has hardly addressed the many issues that arose there. In fact, when it introduced its vocational registration scheme, it went against the recommendations of the Doherty report.

The move that the Government is making with this Bill will be another impediment to the operation of a free market and it will hide inefficiencies from the scrutiny of market forces. It will not address the problems faced by isolated pharmacists who are unable to close or amalgamate and who will derive insufficient solace from an essential pharmacy allowance.

This legislation brings Big Brother into the pharmacy industry like never before. Any aspect of pharmacists' premises can be scrutinised before they set up shop. If the premises are not located where the Government desires, pharmaceutical benefits can be refused. Have honourable senators ever heard anything like it? Having done research into the matter, I may want to set up a pharmacy in a certain place, but if it is not where Big Brother thinks I should put it, my pharmaceutical benefits might be refused. Amalgamation, closure and the payment of essential pharmacy allowances will only apply to approved pharmacy premises. And who in essence is Big Brother? It is not the restructuring authority, but the Minister, who sets the guidelines, and the Secretary of the Department, who has the power to veto all the decisions of the authority.

Despite concern within the pharmacy industry about the Government-Pharmacy Guild agreement, the guidelines for this restructuring have virtually been set in concrete by the agreement. If clause 9 of the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill is passed, it is doubtful whether this Parliament will have any real say in relation to the contents of the guidelines. But I suppose that is not a problem for this Government, which would prefer Parliament to disappear so that nothing is scrutinised.

For one, I know that there is already concern that the redundancy package does not properly reflect the number of years a pharmacist may have put into his business before it is forced to close down. If the guidelines have already been rubber-stamped by the tribunal in accordance with clause 9, Parliament may have little power to properly scrutinise this and other aspects of the package.

I am pleased to see that the Government has extended the privacy provisions of the health insurance and national health Acts to those who knowingly disclose, solicit or receive personal information. However, I wish to make two points. First, it is pharmacists who will be affected most by these new provisions. The Government has an obligation to ensure that they are properly informed about them. Secondly, the Health Insurance Commission has a duty to make its own databases far more secure than they are at present.

Honourable senators may be interested to know that in the recent Senate Estimates hearings-and my colleague Senator Walters was present for those hearings-the Commission admitted that the present claims transmission system between pharmacists and the Commission was probably the easiest type of system to hack into. A pharmacist may transmit data to the Health Insurance Commission by computer via the telephone-indeed, it is planned to have a black box with a dedicated line-but next year all pharmacists will be expected to link up with the Commission through the claims transmission system. In a Freudian way, I kept calling it the compulsory transmission system. Now I know why I was giving it that title-next year it will indeed be a compulsory claims transmission system. The Senate Committee was told, with not a blush on the Minister's face, that it is the easiest system to hack into. Senator Coulter knows, and I know, that there are particular drugs prescribed for people who would be very embarrassed if the community or a local high school hacker knew about them. People would not want it to be known that they were being prescribed AZT or some sort of drug for a fungal infection, for example. Some people know enough about drugs to know the diseases for which they are prescribed, such as drugs used to treat genital herpes. That sort of stuff will be available if people hack into the system. Not only that, but no effective tracking systems are in place to trace the perpetrators of these crimes. There is no point in saying that something is illegal if there are no systems in place to prevent people from breaching the law and to catch them when the law is broken.

I put it to honourable senators that it is an appalling state of affairs that the Health Insurance Commission and the Minister at the Estimates Committee hearings showed not one skerrick of embarrassment at the fact that this was the easiest system to hack into. Innocent people are having scripts filled for very confidential treatments, and any high school hacker is able to get into the system.

This Bill is another example of hastily contrived, poorly thought through, short term fixes-in this case, short term fixes on pharmacists. We have seen similar examples in this chamber. Likewise, the changes to Medicare that I have outlined are not only uncaring and unnecessary, but demonstrate again that this Government is ill equipped to resurrect our failing health care system. The people who will be affected are those who travel overseas, people who are representing our country in industry, sport and academia. They will be the people who will get hurt when they find that they are not insured. They will pay the Medicare levy and receive no benefits. Honourable senators will know that earlier I moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading, and I give notice that at the committee stage I will move an amendment to subclause 31 (b).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, which, as Senator Patterson has already pointed out, seeks to amend several other pieces of legislation. I shall be addressing only those parts which relate to the medical aspects and Senator Lees will later be speaking to other aspects dealing with child welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth while reflecting on some of the history of the pharmaceutical aspects of the Bill-aspects to which Senator Patterson alluded, but which it is worth while dealing with in some detail. Senators will recall that over about 18 months there has been a great deal of consternation among pharmacists throughout the country because of the actions of this Government in seeking to impose on them for pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) drugs conditions of repayment which were totally unsatisfactory and would have led to the demise of many pharmacies.

During the time leading up to the last election many senators will recall going around the country and seeing a large number of pharmacy windows plastered with anti-Government and anti-Hawke statements in relation to the attempted imposition of a Remuneration Tribunal determination which would have contained no element of mark-up on drugs and in which the dispensing fee was quite inadequate. At that time we dealt with the Remuneration Tribunal's determination proposal, and I believe I pointed out-and it is worth repeating-that the Government seemed to be mixing two quite independent factors. The first was the factor of the increasing costs of the pharmaceutical benefits system and the other was the problem it perceived of having too many pharmacies.

As Senator Patterson has rightly pointed out, the size of the PBS is determined by the number of prescriptions written and dispensed, and really has nothing whatever to do with the number of pharmacies. If there was only one pharmacy in Australia, if the same number of prescriptions were written and if that pharmacy dispensed all those prescriptions, the cost to the PBS would remain exactly the same. The number of pharmacies and the cost to the PBS do not relate sensibly to each other. In the legislation that we have before us there is still confusion between the increasing cost to the PBS and the number of pharmacies.

I speak first to this element of the creation of a pharmacy structuring authority. The Government seeks to put in place an authority to make payments to those pharmacies that choose to amalgamate or to go out of business and reduce the number of pharmacies. As Senator Patterson has already pointed out, the parts in this legislation dealing with that aspect also relate to clause 9 of the pharmaceutical benefits legislation with which we will be dealing later. Clause 9 in that legislation seeks to set in place a mechanism by which, if the Guild or a body representing the majority of pharmacists agrees with the Government over a set of conditions, there is a possibility that that mechanism is frozen out for pharmacists who disagree with the Guild or pharmacists who are not members of the Guild and who are appearing before the tribunal. The mechanism which that agreement seeks to put in place relates to the closure of pharmacies and to the creation of this restructuring authority.

It seems passing strange that a Government which is committed to a deregulatory approach to industry in a general sense should in this particular case be seeking to very tightly regulate the pharmacy industry in an attempt to control the number of pharmacies. It is abundantly clear that the Democrats are not given to an unregulated free enterprise system. Nonetheless-I make this observation in passing-the Government seems to be given to a deregulatory approach. Yet, in this instance, where one has a free enterprise system which has been operating, the Government seems to be seeking to impose on that a system of control to close down a number of pharmacies and then to set up a restructuring authority on which the Guild will have representation in order to manage pay-outs and conditions of retirement of those pharmacies.

In a rather anomalous way, we support the sentiments of the words in subclause 5 of the second reading amendment which Senator Patterson is seeking to append to this legislation. We do this for quite different reasons to the Opposition, because it seems to sit rather peculiarly with this Government.

The other part of this legislation which we are dealing with relates to the Medicare benefit gap. As Senator Patterson pointed out in her speech immediately before mine, the gap is increased from $20 to $26. That seems to be a very large increase in the gap over a very short time. However, the idea that this gap should then be indexed seems quite a good idea. If we index that to the consumer price index, we find some difficulty with clause 2 of the Opposition's second reading amendment in which Senator Patterson seeks to condemn the Government for providing automatic consumer price index (CPI) indexation. She has been critical of the increases occurring so far and yet she objects to the gap being indexed to the CPI.

Dealing with the other aspects of this legislation, in particular the aspect which relates to the inability of those who are overseas to claim Medicare benefits, it has been explained to me by government officers as a device, not so much to deny Australians who go overseas the amounts to which they would be entitled were they still in Australia, but to make them well aware that in many countries-to take two examples, the United States and Japan-medical costs are extremely high. Those people may well go overseas with a false sense of security thinking that they were covered by Medi- care but finding that if they had a need for hospitalisation in either of those countries the Medicare repayments would be very meagre.

I can see Senator Patterson's point that while people are continuing to pay the Medicare levy they should be entitled in fairness to whatever amount they are entitled to under the levy. If even a few Australians are caught in countries such as America or Japan with very large medical bills and very small recompense from Medicare, because they believed that they were more extensively covered, it may well be safer to remove that and to run an education program such as the Government intends to run. Senator Patterson, in subclause 3 of her attachment, has alluded to running a more extensive education program to explain to the people who go overseas that they are not covered and that it is absolutely necessary that they take out private cover. That cover would be related to the countries they were visiting; in those countries with very high medical costs, the costs of the cover would be correspondingly high. At least under those circumstances those people would have adequate cover.

There is a certain ambivalence in that aspect of this legislation. There are arguments of a justice type which would support the position taken by Senator Patterson, and presumably by the Opposition, and there are arguments in terms of clarity and of attempting to ensure that patients, who become ill in high medical cost countries, are adequately covered. It is difficult to make a judgment between those two approaches.

The other clauses which Senator Patterson has sought to place in her second reading amendment relate to subclause 1 in which Senator Patterson is calling on the Government to allow patients to insure against the gap-the difference between the scheduled fee and the medical benefit. In the past the Government has sought to maintain this gap for two reasons. One was quite strongly supported by some sections of the Opposition, and that is, to make patients aware of the costs of medical treatment and to place--

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly so, Senator.

—Yes, and to place some inhibition in the way of overuse of the system. Again I find it passing strange that it is now the Opposition which seeks to remove that impediment. Bearing in mind-I think this was also in the Government's mind-if we allow insurance to go into that gap, at once we remove that awareness of the cost and we also immediately give an advantage to those who are better able to insure themselves against that gap. The imposition of a rule which prevents people from insuring against that gap puts everybody on exactly the same level.

SPEECH.PARA: Another motive in the Government's mind is that as much as it possibly can it is attempting to get doctors to charge the schedule fee and to bulk bill. That may well be an argument which was not raised by Senator Patterson but with which she might have some complaint.

On balance, and bearing in mind that the second reading amendment to be moved by Senator Patterson will not have force in law, I think I would probably support it because I think there are several items in it which are useful in bringing home to the Government the inconsistency of its approach between deregulation in some parts of industry and strong regulation in the pharmacy industry. The very good paragraph (3) calls on the Government to increase its education program; paragraph (1) relates to the allowance, in this instance, of gap insurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 before the Senate deals with three separate Acts-the Child Care Act, the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act. I will deal with them one at a time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Child Care Act is aimed at subsidising all those parents who are at present being forced into the work force by the Government's high interest rates and the resulting low living standards. A survey used by the Australian Institute of Family Studies shows that 53.3 per cent of women with preschool children have been forced to take a second family job to save their home and to make ends meet. Only 17.3 per cent of those women work because they enjoy it. It is no wonder when we get an article in the Sydney Morning Herald with the headline `Hawke era ``worst since WWI'' '. The article states:
Living standards of Australian wage earners have fallen further during the period of the Hawke Government than in any other decade since World War I, according to a new study.

The study, conducted by the dean of economics at Murdoch University in Perth, Professor Keith Norris, found that the fall between 1982 and 1988 varied for average income earners between 2.2 per cent (for single adult female) and 10.2 per cent (for a household with two children on average male earnings).

When we have that situation there is a need for child-care places. Because women have been forced into the work force by this Government's policies amendments to the Child Care Act have been seen as necessary. Quite frankly, due to this Government's policies and the increase in demand there are just not enough child-care places. Till now government assistance to child-care centres has been limited to those run by so-called eligible organisations.

This legislation will allow government assistance in the form of fee relief to be provided for eligible child-care centres operated on a commercial basis by commercial organisations, be they private or government operated. Other financial assistance, such as recurrent grants, et cetera, will be available only to non-profit organisations as they are at present and local government authorities. So far, so good.
My main area of concern is what is meant by proposed new section 4C. I would like to read it because it is of great concern to me. Proposed new section 4C. (1) states:
The Minister may make guidelines, not inconsistent with this Act, with respect to the exercise of any of the Minister's powers under section 4B.
Proposed new section 4B. sets out who will get the money. Proposed new section 4C. (2) states:
A guideline is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

It sounds innocuous enough, but what on earth will these guidelines contain? There has been a report to the Government. That report recommends that there should be an accreditation system for child-care centres. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spoke about this at the time of the election. Does proposed new section 4C mean that the commercial centres that pass this accreditation will get funding under this fee relief for their clients, and only those centres which have the accreditation system?

Let us have a look at the need for an accreditation system. The principle of an accreditation system is motherhood stuff. Accreditation would set certain standards that child-care centres would have to abide by. We all agree that the best possible standards for our children are necessary at an affordable rate. I would like to stress that. However, presently the responsibility for these standards is at State government level. All those State governments jealously guard these responsibilities.

If on top of these State government standards the Federal Government inflicts its own requirements, then we will be falling into that age-old trap of double banking and all the associated costs that incurs. I believe that we should leave the standards to the States, where they rightly belong. I will just give one example of States sending round their inspectors to make sure that the child-care centres are abiding by their standards, and the Commonwealth sending round its inspectors to make sure that its standards are abided by-a field day for bureaucrats and a tremendous additional cost to the Government and, therefore, to the taxpayer. I believe that we should keep these sorts of double banking costs to a minimum.

Let the Commonwealth look at the standards of all the States. If it believes that any State is below par, let the Ministers get together and thrash it out. I believe that is the way it should be done. Additional costs should not be imposed by sending out inspectors one on top of the other. We have that in other legislation, and nursing home care is a typical example.

If section 4C does mean accreditation, why is the Government not coming clean and saying so instead of just referring to standards? Why are we asked to pass legislation which refers vaguely to guidelines? What is this disallowable instrument that could stop certain child-care centres getting fee relief for their clients? This is one of the many questions I will be putting to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) when he comes before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. As I say, this is one of the benefits of the new committee system that the Senate is working under.

Let me now turn to the amendments to the Health Insurance Act. The Government has increased the maximum contribution the patient pays. The gap between the schedule fee and the Medicare benefit was $20 and will be increased to $26 from 1 January 1991. It will also be indexed. Again, that safety net has been treated in the same way. This is another area of the Medicare benefit being increased.
I will now move to the restructuring of the pharmaceutical industry in the Health Insurance Act. This Bill introduces a system that has been agreed upon by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia.

The Bill seeks to set up a pharmacy restructuring authority. The Government believes that there are far too many chemist shops in many areas of Australia and it is prepared to give those pharmacists who no longer want to carry on with their pharmacies or who are not viable a subsidy to close down.

Let us have a look at the subsidy which the Government has offered. This buy-out is based on the number of years of ownership. I believe that the buy-out is something that we must look at very closely. If one has owned a pharmacy for up to three years the buy-out is $45,000; between four and five years it is $50,000; between six and seven years it is $55,000; between eight and nine years it is $60,000; between 10 and 11 years it is $65,000; between 12 and 13 years it is $70,000; between 14 and 15 years it is $75,000; and between 16 years and over it is $80,000. The Government is going to pay half of these amounts.

A pharmacy which has been running for 16 years and over will be paid $80,000 of which the Australian taxpayer will pay half. The pharmacists throughout Australia pay the other half. In the first year pharmacists will be charged a levy of 1c per prescription. In the second year they will be charged 2c, in the third year 3c, in the fourth year 4c and so on until the debt is paid.

To what extent should country pharmacists who have been very viable and looked after themselves be responsible for funding the closure of pharmacies in the suburbs of Melbourne or Sydney? It is quite beyond belief that this arrangement should have been agreed to. But this is the agreement that the Guild and the Government have come to.

The Government has no intention of allowing market forces to work. The Government will just say who the pharmacists are and pay them for closing down. On the other side of the coin, any pharmacist who wants to open up in an area will have to register with the new authority before he can sell pharmaceutical benefit drugs which attract a patient subsidy.
Let us look at the independence of this authority. It is pretty important that we know who are making these decisions. According to the explanatory memorandum:
The membership of the Authority will be made up of Government and industry nominees with an independent Chairperson, all appointed by the Minister.
The Authority will make its recommendations in accordance with criteria determined by the Minister.

The Pharmacy Guild will be able to suggest four nominations. The Government will take its pick and two of those nominees will be appointed. The restructuring authority will be made up of government members and industry nominees. The Government will appoint the lot. It will appoint the chairman, it will choose two members from the four nominations put up by the Guild and, of course, it will appoint its own officers. That is how independent that authority will be. It will be interesting to see just what occurs as a result of that so called independence.

At the moment the National Health Act prevents the release of data on pharmaceutical benefits scheme products held by the Department of Community Services and Health where a product category attracts fewer than three suppliers. This has been done in the past so that data cannot lead to the identification of a manufacturer. The Government is doing away with this secrecy provision. It is allowing data to be made public if fewer than three manufacturers are involved. As a result, very confidential information will be made available. I believe that that is totally wrong. It is something about which the Opposition will be moving an amendment.

The last matter I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate is something that I could not even find in the outline of explanatory memorandum. I refer to a matter relating to clause 17 about which Senator Patterson spoke at great length-that is, the Government's decision that people who go overseas for a length of time are not entitled to Medicare cover. People in this category pay their taxes in Australia. They pay their Medicare levy. Academics who go overseas for 12 months, or perhaps for even a shorter period, are not entitled to Medicare cover. Although these people pay their taxes, they are not entitled to Medicare cover if they happen to be overseas.

The Government has told us that it is making this change to clarify the situation. The Government says that people who go overseas are not aware that they are entitled to Medicare cover. Because of this, the Government says that it is going to scrub the Medicare cover that these people receive when they are in Australia. The Government is not going to stop the payment of their Medicare levy. Oh, no-that goes straight into the Government coffers. But it is stopping them getting any benefit from the Medicare levy that they pay while they are overseas. There is absolutely no justification for that at all.

The Government has tried to hide its intention in this respect by not mentioning it in any of the literature that it has put out. This provision is tucked away in clause 17 of the Bill. If the Government is desperately trying to prop up Medicare because it is going broke and sending the country broke, it has to look at other means of doing so than shonky ones such as that. As Senator Patterson has already indicated, the Opposition will be supporting the general thrust of the legislation. Senator Patterson has already moved an amendment, which I support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a number of points in supporting the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I hope to refute some of the claims that have been made by Opposition senators who have spoken during the debate on this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: When I read a community services and health legislation amendment Bill that amends the Child Care Act 1972, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953 I have to sympathise with the community which has to try to understand exactly what is happening. While I can see the rationality for the legislation and why the Government has introduced it-and members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills have made this point from time to time-I think this practice adds confusion to an understanding of these issues.

Given the way that legislation proceeds in this place, it is understandable that an attempt is made to group together matters in the one portfolio area or matters that relate to each other, even if they occur under different Acts within that one portfolio. But this does make it difficult for the community. I sincerely hope that people are aware of the very significant changes encompassed in this amending Bill.

In particular-it would be no surprise to my colleagues opposite-I wish to make some comments about the child-care changes under this legislation. Honourable senators opposite would certainly know of my continuing interest in child-care and of my real pleasure in being able to support the proposed changes to the Child Care Act contained in this piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A truly great contribution you have made, Senator Crowley.

—I thank Senator Faulkner for that comment. I accept that. I also accept this Government's truly great contribution to child-care. When the Government came to office there were only 46,000 funded child-care places in the country; there are now 122,000. The numbers have nearly tripled. When the Government came into office there were no systematic means of fee relief to support affordable child-care. It is interesting to note that from 1 October this year, at best guess, an estimated 90,000 families using non-profit community based centres will benefit from the more generous targeted fee relief system. It is estimated that a further 35,000 families will enjoy those benefits come 1 January next year, when they will be using commercial centres.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitment to child-care in this legislation incorporates the needs-based planning for 80,000 new child-care places in the community based centres. We have continuing government commitment by its extending the number of community child-care places, by its increasing and extending fee relief into the non-profit and commercial child-care centres, and by its providing affordability and accessibility to many more places. Clearly the demand in the community is huge. The Government has implemented these mechanisms to try to extend the child-care so as to best meet the demands and the needs of men and women in the community who clearly indicate that they want to use it.
This Government is committed to making child-care affordable and accessible, with principles of equity and standards of quality. There is no point in providing child-care with no regard to quality.

I certainly take issue with Senator Walters's points about the setting of standards and accreditation. In times past she and I have crossed swords about how we split words, and no doubt we will do it again. Those of us who are old enough-I will put Senator Walters and me in that category-can remember when child-care in this country was an absolute disgrace. Many people raised concerns about child-care because they had the opportunity to visit and see for themselves some very insufficient provisions of child-care that were available in various communities. That is one of the reasons that publicly funded community based child-care was instituted. It has set the standards and it continues to maintain the standards of what is regarded as optimal child-care; that is, affordable child-care that, at the same time, has quality. We do not want to revert to times when children were drugged and kept asleep all day in some kind of sleeping arrangement so that the one or two people caring for them could cope with up to 30 children or more, as we can remember from years ago.

We also know that the standards in a child-care centre need to be given very serious consideration. We have heard it said, and we have certainly seen it quoted, that any caring person-indeed, some people would say even a 15-year-old girl; although sometimes a boy-is able to look after children. Most of us would appreciate that nobody would settle for insufficient or woofy guidelines requiring only `a caring person', particularly for all-day care or for child minding or baby sitting in the evenings. Indeed, I do not think anybody in this chamber would support the notion that child-care could be adequately undertaken by a 15-year-old. We need to look at standards. We need to look at the accreditation process so that those minimal standards of acceptable childcare are either instituted or maintained.

Senator Walters claimed that we would be adding a second tier of bureaucrats and that Commonwealth inspectors would be traipsing around from child-care centre to child-care centre, hot on the heels of the State inspectors. Good stuff, but entirely unsubstantiated, and certainly not the Government's intention.

The Government intends to tackle this issue in cooperation with the State and local governments. I do not have any understanding that the Commonwealth Government intends to take over what is properly and reasonably the responsibility of State governments. Standards of child-care currently differ from State to State. It is not unreasonable to look at making sure the standards-when we use the expression `minimal standards'-are sufficient and fairly equal. We need to offer to the citizens that kind of guarantee. If, in talking to the States, we can come up with an agreed set of minimum standards and an agreed way that that inspection or accreditation process will be optimally carried out, I am quite sure that Senator Walters will find that that is the way it will happen. Commonwealth inspectors will not be traipsing around after State inspectors. Certainly this Government, in this legislation, is looking to cost constraint. It will not be implementing a crazy, extravagant process of that sort.

I would have thought that in her heart, Senator Walters would have agreed that some kind of minimum standards for child-care are necessary. Certainly I would argue it very strongly.
