The challenge for all Government senators-particularly me-over the last year or so has been to grapple with a change in Party policy to allow the extension of public dollars to the private sector in child-care. It seemed to us, as a matter of equity, that people should not be denied access to child-care places in the private sector because of cost. We certainly saw that, if as a matter of equity, fee relief could be reasonably extended to people using private childcare centres, then as a quid pro quo or a trade-off, we would say that we wanted the sorts of minimum standards in those private child-care centres that occurred in the commercial child-care centres. I am glad that Senator Patterson smiles; I take that smile to be an assent to that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator Crowley.
—Oh! You do not want optimal standards.
—I wasn't paying total attention.

—Senator Patterson does not wish me to interpret her smile; I stand corrected. The community has not yet properly become aware of just how extensive and useful the extension of fee relief to the commercial and non-profit community based centres will be.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only have we extended the fee relief to people using private and not-for-profit child-care community centres, but also we have increased the level of income at which fee relief cuts out. Previously, fee relief cut out at about $35,000. I cannot give an accurate figure on that, but it was around $35,000 or $36,000 for one child. That ceiling has now been extended to $56,200 for one child and $68,600 for two children or more. They are the levels at which fee relief cuts out entirely. Many people currently using the government child-care centres will find that they are eligible for extensive fee relief. In other words, the cost to users of child-care will drop considerably for people within this family income range.

In a number of ways-by extending its commitment to the number of community based child-care centres, by extending fee relief to the non-profit child-care centres and to the commercial or private child-care centres, and by increasing the family income up to which users are eligible for fee relief-this Government has made absolutely beyond any doubt its commitment to affordable child-care of adequate standard.

I do not believe there is any dispute with the thrust of Government policy. More importantly, not only can we say that there is no dispute, but there is a very clear statement by Government in this piece of legislation of its commitment to child-care and to those people in the community who, for whatever reason, decide they would like to use it. I am really very delighted to be able to stand in this Senate tonight and speak on behalf of the child-care changes coming into law, I hope, very soon under this legislation.

One of the other points on which I would like to take issue with Senator Walters is her-I expect, entirely predictable-whack at Medicare as she was concluding her remarks. If I remember, she said that it is Medicare that is dragging this country into massive debt. That is a fair claim for our health system, being, as it is, something like 7.9 per cent of gross national product! If it is all happening in that 8 per cent of expenditure, that is doing very well indeed.

I hope the heavy irony of my remarks makes it clear that I do not accept one line or one word of Senator Walters's claim. Medicare is not an outrageous cost to the community. The challenge for the Government has been, with the introduction of Medicare, to maintain that balance between the delivery of an adequate quality health service and at the same time to set some kind of ceiling, for cost restraint reasons, against the delivery of health care.

Anybody reading in this area would know that that debate is alive and very well in the community at the moment. Also, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) is indicating that his Medicare inquiry would appreciate that they are some of the dimensions he wants to be looked at, that is, the balance of quality health care and matters of proper cost constraint. I do not understand that the Minister has ever indicated any dissatisfaction with Medicare. Indeed, he is on the record as strongly endorsing it, and I would like to put my support of those remarks, too.

It is not Medicare but the many complexities of the health care system we have in this country that are pushing at costs. It is properly the responsibility of government to try to manage that balance between the demands for health care, the demands for hospitalisation, the demands for new hi-tech innovative systems of treatment and methodologies of management of health care and at the same time to properly put some kind of ceiling on the cost to the taxpayers of this country of that health care.

The comments made by, I think, Senator Patterson and Senator Walters in objection to the restriction of Medicare payments to people travelling overseas need to be qualified. First, let me say that any person travelling overseas to a reciprocal health care country--

TALK.START.PARA: —How many are there?

—Actually, that is a very good question, and I can tell the honourable senator. Of the something like two million travellers that leave this country's shores each year, about 600,000 go to reciprocal health care countries. That is quite a large chunk of people whose Medicare payments will cover them entirely for the health costs they would enjoy-if not have to accept-in a reciprocal health care country.

SPEECH.PARA: Those reciprocal health care countries include the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta, Sweden and Italy. The Government is currently in the process-indeed, well advanced in the process-of negotiations for arrangements to include the Netherlands in a reciprocal health arrangement. Denmark and Hungary are also in the process, but at an earlier stage, I believe, of negotiations.

It is also important to say that I was able to discover that any Commonwealth public servants who are required, as part of their work, to live overseas are having their health care provided for by special arrangements through their departments; that is, instead of Medicare making the payments against costs that those public servants might have, the department for which they work will be picking up that cost. Anybody from the Public Service working overseas for a long time also needs to be added to that number of 600,000.

The important point-and I can appreciate why Senator Patterson would want to argue the way she has-is that it is also true that people leaving this country may have a false sense of security in the understanding that Medicare will cover their costs overseas. Indeed, it does not. I would endorse the remarks made by Senator Coulter that there could be a false sense of security, particularly for people travel- ling to a country with which we do not have reciprocal health care arrangements and which has very expensive health care. In particular, I endorse the countries named by Senator Coulter-America and Japan-both countries likely to be visited by a number of people leaving this country.

If one gets a very significant bill for health care-and one certainly would not like to consider the hospital costs that one might get from a hospital stay in America-Medicare does not cover that and, certainly, the return under Medicare for visits to the doctor would be but a fraction of an average cost of a visit to a doctor in those expensive health care countries. In providing this kind of re-arrangement and in urging travellers to appreciate that their health costs are their own while they are out of the country, I think the Government will be assisting to protect people to make sure they do not find themselves saddled with extraordinary health liabilities.

I would like to finish by making some points about the claims by the Opposition that it was pretty outrageous to extend the gap from $20 to $26. `This is a very rapid increase in no time at all', I think Senator Coulter said, but he failed to tell the Senate that that $20 figure was put in place in 1986 and has not increased since then. I suppose that, if one compares today with yesterday, that is a short time space, but if one compares 1990 with 1986 one would have to say that a $6 increase-even to over $20-over four years is not as outrageous as Senator Coulter might lead us to believe.

Importantly, though, I endorse his points made in defence of not allowing insurance to cover the gap. The Opposition quite often in this place has argued strenuously that, if people were able to enjoy what they could call a co-payment or a patient contribution, that would focus their minds on what health care costs and would encourage them not to contribute to overuse of the system. I do not believe the Opposition can argue that way and then say, `Yes, but we will fix it up by allowing people to insure against the gap'. That is a very contradictory argument.

I might say that Senator Patterson is not alone in presenting it. The Australian Medical Association (AMA) is very hot in adding that little contradiction from time to time, too. The advantage of having been thinking about health for a long time is that I have been at meetings-in 1982, I can particularly remember-where the AMA was amongst those who agreed that a gap of 25 per cent was reasonable. That would be the assessment, it said, of administrative costs in a general practice and it would not be unreasonable to have a 75 per cent return. The AMA conveniently forgets to remind people that it was in agreement with those figures at that time.

I think it is perfectly within its rights for the AMA to change its argument as it goes along, but I think the AMA and the Opposition are in a log jam if they want to argue that some kind of constraint on the use of services will be put in place by allowing patients the opportunity to pay a gap but then to go around the corner and completely insure against the cost of it. The only thing that that will do is increase the price of private insurance and negate the effect of there being a co-payment. In particular, it will do nothing to constrain the costs of expenditure on health. Senator Walters wants to say that Medicare is blowing out, but she does not seem to want to oppose this little measure from the Opposition that will exactly and directly increase the push on costs and expenditure in the health area.

I cannot let that kind of contradictory argument go without putting some comment in objection to it. It is the logic of it, in particular, that is offensive: we can have one thing and we cannot have another thing, but that is all right. That is not on, and I would urge Senator Patterson to rethink that part of her contribution.

There is much more that could be said about this package of legislation. As I started, so I would like to conclude. It is of great satisfaction to me to be standing in this Senate supporting this new extension of child-care and fee relief so that many more Australians who indicate that they want child-care will find it not only more available and more accessible but also more affordable. On behalf of those who have been lobbying for that, I am very pleased to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only to that part of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill which deals with the Child Care Act 1972. I begin my remarks by stressing that the Australian Democrats have always had and will continue to have a very strong commitment to the publicly funded child-care system. While we certainly acknowledge that the Government has done a considerable amount in this area, we are concerned that the extension of fee relief may lead down the track to a lack of interest in and lack of support for the publicly funded system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has assured us that this measure will not take financial support away from the community based centres but instead is allocating additional funds, and, of course, this is the case. It is true that this move does not take any money at all from public centres, but we believe that it must ultimately have some impact on the level of funds available for the non-profit sector. After all, it will cost the Government, on its figures, some $28m this financial year, and this is likely to increase to $100m by 1996.

I just wish to put our concerns on the record now. Once the size of the cake is stabilised-indeed, it may decrease in the future-the pressure will be on the most expensive option. If people are cost cutting, they will cut into the public sector. After all, the measure that we have before us tonight creates a cheaper option. These places will be a lot less expensive for the Government to fund.

Under this legislation fee relief for child-care is extended to commercial child-care centres. Certainly, this move will go quite a long way towards addressing a real and growing problem, and that is that many parents face long and difficult waiting lists to place their children in community based centres. The result has been that many parents are forced to place their children in quite unsatisfactory care arrangements-backyard services and in some cases with individuals who do not have the best interests of children at heart. They may in some instances have been forced to travel a considerable distance from their home and from their workplace in order to take the odd place that came up in a community centre.

For some this has meant having to rely on friends and relatives. While this is often not a problem, particularly with elderly relatives, the long term care of very young children can be a considerable burden. For a significant number of women and, I believe, a growing number of men, the difficulties have meant that they have at best been able to re-enter the work force on a part time or temporary basis, and many have been unable to move into the work force at all-and I stress in particular the needs of single parents.

However, despite the reservations I have mentioned, I commend the Government on broadening the definition of child-care centres and on the proposed changes in the fringe benefits tax legislation, which will mean that employer provided facilities are now encouraged. I hope that we will see a very rapid rise in the number of work based child-care centres. At present these centres are not widespread. However, I hope that, as this legislation provides some incentive, as more become available and as employers begin to realise the financial benefits of work based child-care, these services will rapidly spread.

I pause to mention one concern that has been brought to our attention. I just sound a warning that there is already evidence in Melbourne of commercial interests obtaining community based child-care places to establish work based programs. One instance occurred because a community based centre was forced physically to relocate, but there are other instances where commercial interests and businesses have been moving around the community centres attempting to find vacant places-places which have in some instances occurred because parents can no longer meet the gap between what they are refunded and what it costs the commercial centres to operate and therefore what they have to charge.

Therefore, while we applaud the move to the work based centres, we stress that the Government must ensure that these centres are not established at the expense of community based places. They must, in fact, provide additional places.

This Bill means that, in effect, a privately operated centre can claim fee relief if the Minister for Community Services and Health determines that it is eligible for that purpose. Private centres will continue to be ineligible for capital or operational subsidies. We have some concerns along the lines expressed by some members of the Opposition as to exactly what the guidelines will involve. The Minister is empowered to make these guidelines, to be used in determining whether a commercial centre is eligible for fee relief. It is of some concern to us that we are simply not able to comment on these because we have not seen them to this point and we do not have them before us as we debate this legislation tonight.

I appreciate, however, that any guidelines formulated by the Minister under these new provisions will be a disallow- able instrument but, because of their potential significance and their link to the provision of fee relief, I believe that it would have been preferable if we could have had at least some real indication in writing before discussing this legislation.

The Australian Democrats are of the view that the extension of fee relief must be accompanied by a commitment on the part of the Government to a set of national standards, and we will not be supporting any moves to omit or overlook this aspect. It has already been stated that many State regulations set out very clearly what a child-care centre needs to have before it is able to be licensed. However, previous experience at trying to regulate from State to State is enough to ring some alarm bells as to how long it would take to move from State to State and to get a real guarantee of uniform standards across all States.

Therefore, we believe that national guidelines can and should be linked in some way to the funds that are being made available by the Government. I am not in any way suggesting that the Government should duplicate existing State licensing requirements. Currently State regulations relate primarily to input, particularly to physical requirements, building codes, record keeping, health and hygiene requirements, insurance obligations, et cetera.

We see that the Commonwealth's role in establishing national guidelines should be focused more on developing a set of quality of care standards for centres. These issues are certainly not addressed by all States and frequently not addressed at all for State licensing regulations. We would see these guidelines as involving such matters as policy consistency, the fact that affordability must be ensured with the fee relief and that there should be no rise in the cost to parents-in other words, no inflation in prices-and the need for priority of access to the service for low income families, particularly those most in need of child-care.

Any national accreditation scheme will need to go a long way beyond just the physical standards set out in most State regulations, as I said earlier. We believe that the national standards must involve outcomes: the benefits to the children; how they will benefit from their time in child-care. It is of considerable concern to us that some should suggest that these national guidelines are not necessary. I particularly make note of the length of time that some children spend each day in child-care. It is no longer just a brief couple of hours to give mum respite while she does some shopping. As Senator Walters pointed out, a vast number of working women now rely on child-care and children are in child-care centres for eight or nine hours a day. Therefore, I think it is essential that we keep track of how they are treated and the types of programs and stimulating activities they are offered.

The industry has now been part of the consultative process. It has been apparently a very involved period of discussions in looking at accreditation. I believe that the industry generally recognises that there are some operators whose standards need to be questioned. The industry itself generally recognises and accepts the desirability of an accreditation program. I understand from information received just yesterday that the Committee is in fact looking at a self-support model rather than at a system whereby there is external monitoring from some government department. I certainly look forward to seeing the draft proposals, and I hope that the close consultation with the industry and those involved will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all recognise the importance of child-care to Australian families, and therefore the desirability of ensuring that not only is the quality of child-care adequate but also that it is affordable. I think in many ways the debate comes down to the priorities that ought to be accorded to those two desirable goals. Therefore, I think the Government has belatedly recognised-albeit in an election context-that it is indeed desirable that if we are to accord fee relief it should be across the board and at least be extended to the private sector in the way that the Government is proposing to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The non-commercial sector still gets very significant assistance that is denied to the private sector by way of exemptions from sales tax, capital grants, recurrent grants, establishment grants and the like. But we certainly support the principle of the extension of fee relief to the private sector. We are very conscious of the fact that the Government had to be dragged screaming and yelling to the barrier on this issue. It was in the face of trenchant opposition from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) over a period of years, and indeed from the Department of Community Services and Health.

I think there is very much an undercurrent or hidden agenda in a lot of the debate that goes on in this area. Nonetheless, the Government finally, in desperation at the thought that it might lose the last election, did a Faustian deal with the ACTU, which involved allowing the ACTU going quiet on the extension but in return getting a promise that a national accreditation system would be put in place.

We have the most serious concerns about that concept, because the starting point ought surely to be that one does not need a national system-which the Government chooses to describe as complementary but which we would describe as a classic case of duplication-unless one is able to demonstrate that the State system is not working effectively. There will always be variations in quality, and I do not think that the Australian Democrats would pretend for a moment that even if one had the most exhaustive and expensive system of quality control one could somehow guarantee that all child-care centres are going to measure up to the same uniform standards, or indeed provide the same uniform outcomes. It is a nonsense proposition and I am sure very few would try to defend it.

But that, of course, has not stopped people aspiring to what I think is a quite unrealistic goal. It is in that context that I think we need to understand why this whole accreditation system is being put in place, because it seems clear to me that one cannot expect to set out standards in terms of quality, and then expect to deliver certain outcomes. The most one can do is to ensure that there are not abuses in the system and that people are very much aware of what they are getting for their money. That means putting the onus on the parents. There is nothing particularly heinous about that or indeed, I would not have thought, controversial.

It is extraordinary in this area that one actually gets child-care specialists saying such things as, `Child-care is too important to be left to parents'. Senator Walsh, in an excellent article recently, quoted from another such hysterical statement. It states:
Talkback radio reflects the view that anyone who is nice and motherly can look after children. This is a fallacy.

That view does permeate the industry and indeed I think it also permeates the bureaucracy at a number of levels. So, one has this extraordinary notion that somehow we cannot trust parents to look after their children as though parents are indifferent. What we have to do is bring in some bureaucrats to make sure it all happens for them, and in the process create whole new career structures and indeed inevitably add very significantly to the cost of child-care.

I do not have much doubt that this debate at the present time is being driven by those sorts of considerations in reality, even if they are not confessed too openly, and that is a matter of great concern to us. We do not see the need for an accreditation system, and nor have we been made aware of any significant deficiencies in the State system. Each State has an exhaustive set of regulations-I have not bothered to bring in the wad of material which would demonstrate that-but there is no doubt at all that there is another easy doctorate of philosophy to be gained by doing an assessment of the comparative requirements of State and Territory regulations.

If there are some problems-and they cannot be significant or else we would have heard about them-then it is a very simple matter for the relevant Federal Minister to convene a meeting of State colleagues to consider the matter at a ministerial council. That could be done, and no doubt the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), will go through those motions at some later time. But it certainly should not be used as an excuse for somehow justifying this whole new system that the Government wants to put in place. I suppose what makes one most suspicious of all about this is that the Act itself says absolutely nothing about accreditation, and it says only the vaguest things about guidelines. If one looks at the principal Act, it actually provides for fee relief to the non-commercial sector to be granted in accordance with guidelines prescribed by the Minister.

But yet, when we come to this Act, we find that the Minister may make guidelines not inconsistent with this Act with respect to the exercise of any of the Minister's powers. That is in relation both to fee relief and to capital and recurrent grants. What that means is that the Minister is absolutely at large. In other words, he can proclaim any guidelines he likes on any topic that he likes and he can then totally ignore them if he wishes.

I find that an extraordinary and preposterous proposition. It fortifies the concern that we have that the second reading speech makes absolutely no mention of any accreditation system. The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill itself makes absolutely no mention of any accreditation system, and yet we know that it is all going on behind the scenes. It has been exhaustively documented, and I think Senator Lees made mention of the final meeting of this mickey mouse outfit called the Committee of Child-Care Industry Representatives on a National Accreditation System for Child-Care Services.

If ever one has seen a loaded gathering, it is that one; it has as a very clear minority a couple of almost token representatives of the private sector and it is totally dominated by people who have a very serious antipathy towards the concept of extending fee relief to the private sector, let alone wanting it to blossom. Their whole aim is to restrict it as much as possible. I give the Senate one example of the sort of thinking that tends to dominate in these areas, and to show that the cost of services and the choice of parents is absolutely the last agenda item.
The Tasmanian Association of Children's Services wrote, I think, to quite a number of members and senators seeking support for an accreditation system. It starts off by saying:
The position of our Association is that `accreditation is essentially a process of quality control and quality improvement'.

No mention at all of the cost; it is simply a matter of keeping tight control over the system and then raising the standards. In themselves I suppose they are laudable aspirations, and indeed in one sense we would hope that over time all of society improves in terms of quality, but we cannot pretend that somehow bureaucrats are able to deliver quality control and quality improvement simply by promulgating endless regulations and rules. The latest little effort which came to my attention yesterday is a 28-page document which is supposed to provide instructions on how fee relief entitlement is calculated for each eligible family, the process for recording fee and fee relief details, and the claiming of reimbursement from the Commonwealth. These are supposedly details of the proposed administrative arrangements, including a draft recordkeeping system and associated instructions.

Endless opportunities exist for those who want to make a career out of regulation, but it has nothing to do with quality control. All it will do is lead to an increase in costs. We only have to look at the report to the Minister by that Committee of Child Care Industry Representatives which, as I say, is very much a one-sided selection. I do not regard that as a true Committee of Child Care Industry Representatives; it is just part of this entirely disingenuous and misleading exercise that the Minister, Mr Staples, has been engaging in for some months now to try to hoodwink the public into thinking that somehow nothing much is on the agenda other than the proposal to extend fee relief in accordance with some guidelines that he might proclaim down the track.

As Senator Lees rightly pointed out, the high watermark of the absurdity of all this is that, in order to qualify for fee relief, the commercial centres will have to undertake to comply with guidelines which are not yet in existence and centres will have until the end of the next calendar year to do that. That again is an extraordinary situation. The centres are being held over a barrel, told that they will not get their money unless they undertake to sign up on something which at this stage is sight unseen.

One can understand the degree of concern in the commercial sector, to the point where centres have been talking seriously about not even wanting to accept fee relief. I suspect that parents will share the concerns of the centres when they see what this will do for costs. Despite some of the assurances that one is given that these guidelines will be fairly limited in scope and will perhaps only apply to some matters which we would all regard as desirable, such as the level of insurance cover to be taken out and whether centres comply with State and Territory regulations, whether they provide proper priority of access rules and whether they provide for proper accounting and audit standards, the fact of the matter is that these guidelines will range far and wide.

I was very concerned to hear the Democrats, through Senator Lees, suggest that somehow this was what it ought to be all about, that we need a national accreditation system so that we can have these so called quality standards in place. If ever there was a false dawn, it is that. I cannot possibly see how anyone can have any confidence that we can guarantee quality control at the Federal level any more than we can do it at the State level. Nonetheless, if we look at the report of the Committee, these are some of the gems that we find:

The Committee noted that while feedback was generally supportive, there was concern and some opposition from State based child-care associations. A small number of these associations opposed the establishment of a national accreditation body or system while others simply wanted a role for State branches of the proposed national body.

That is a grotesque understatement of the level of concern. The private sector is bitterly opposed to any such accreditation system or to making fee relief conditional upon adherence to those standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they opposed to getting the fee relief?

—If Senator Collins had been listening he would know that I have just said they are. That is the level of concern they have about accreditation. If he does not believe me-he who wanders in late and does not listen--
—I have kids in child-care centres. I do know a bit about the subject.
—Does that make him an expert? I think it does.
—Does it make you an expert?

—I am agreeing with him. I think it does qualify us if we are users of the service. The tragedy of the matter is that instead of letting users like Senator Collins and me and everyone else make some sort of subjective judgment of the child-care centres that we use, what is going to happen is that these careerists in the industry are the ones who will decide whether the standards are high enough for Senator Collins' children, no matter whether Senator Collins might be satisfied with the standard of service that he has received or happy with the price he has paid to date. The Government will tell him that the standards have to be jacked up and it will not give a damn whether that means that the fees rise accordingly. So Senator Collins and others in the community who regard themselves as consumers of the service will have virtually no input and no choice. Those people will simply be landed with something that someone else regards as an improvement in the system at considerably greater expense.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the first proposition, that the private sector is so adamantly opposed to this that it is seriously talking about rejecting fee relief. Senator Collins's close colleague, Senator Walsh, at a meeting in Sydney last week urged it not to reject fee relief despite a strong inclination to do so. That is the first sort of canard we get in this area. The report also goes on to say:

A number of State child-care associations also expressed concern at the link between accreditation and fee relief eligibility. The Committee considered all views carefully, but in formulating final recommendations has acknowledged the weight of community support for both accreditation and a mechanism that can provide assurances of quality in all services attracting fee relief.

That is preposterous hypocrisy. There is no weight of community support for accreditation. There is indeed very strong self-interest amongst the industry professionals and the child-care careerists who see this as a wonderful opportunity to expand their horizons. But to pretend that somehow there is a weight of community support out there for accreditation is preposterous nonsense and it flies in the face of the report's later call for a very substantial major public awareness campaign to increase community understanding of the value of a new national accreditation system. It is complete and utter nonsense. It is self-serving rubbish. If we look closely at what the report says, it does not deny the link between accreditation and fee relief eligibility.

It says that a number of State child-care associations also expressed concern at the link, but it does not pretend that there will not be a link. Yet there is not a skerrick of suggestion in the Bill that there will be any such nexus, nothing in the second reading speech, nothing in anything the Minister has ever said publicly on the record. Yet we know, by reading this report of the Committee, that it is a fact of life. This is the hidden agenda, this is the Trojan horse. The Government is going to wheel in accreditation after it has given the Minister a carte blanche entitlement to introduce any guidelines that suit the Minister and then ignore those guidelines when it suits him as well. We will end up with the best or worst of all possible worlds, and that will depend entirely, I suspect, on what view we take of consumers' rights.

The Opposition takes the view that parents ought to come first, not the professionals; that this is not an area that is too important to leave to parents. Indeed, parents ought to be the primary concern. For all that it does not say about this major agenda item, in many ways that is what the Bill is all about. Our concern is simply heightened by the exclusion of references to this scheme. That is why we have to turn to reports like this, which certainly are not widely available to the public and could not possibly have led to any community support for the concept. This is where the report laughingly uses terms such as, `We are in favour of a complementary system to State/Territory licensing regulations'. Who knows why there is a need for complementary regulations? What is wrong with State and Territory regulations? If there is something wrong with them, the Government should convene a meeting of the ministerial council and do something about it. It should not wheel in this whole new system, this new layer of regulation, that can do nothing but add to the costs.

The report goes on to talk about quality factors and it identifies a number of these which it says include: quality and safety of building, health and safety of indoor and outdoor environment, group size, staff : child ratio, qualifications of staff, award pay and conditions. These are all matters regulated at State level or in the Industrial Relations Commission. There is not a problem about any of those. Then the report goes on to talk about how much further it would like to go:

The Committee examined and nominated a number of conditions for fee relief which it recommends should operate for child-care centres from 1 January 1991. These included a stipulation that centres must be child-care centres as defined-
that is all right-
and thus must meet requirements to open a minimum number of hours and weeks per year-
that is all right-
and compliance with the kind of legal requirements outlined in the first list of quality factors above.

That is all about workers rights in many ways, and I think it is simply again self-serving nonsense to pretend that there is some level of staff : child ratio or group size that is appropriate across the community. It is all a function of how much we want to spend on the system. We can have a 1 : 1 arrangement if we want it, but everyone else knows it is prohibitively expensive and we will not do it. As Senator Walsh pointed out to that very interesting Sydney meeting, it makes little sense to require four-year-olds to be supervised by one staff member per group of 10 and yet a year later, when the children turn 5, to be looked after at school in groups of, say, 25 cared for by one teacher. I seek leave at this stage to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Collins)-by leave-agreed to:

That the order of the Senate of 24 August 1990, requiring the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure to present its report on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990 and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 by 18 October 1990 be altered to provide that the Committee presents its report by 12 November 1990.
Bills received from the House of Representatives.

Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990

Mr President, this Bill is the Government's next major piece of anti-avoidance legislation. It contains provisions to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to give effect to the proposal, as announced in the Economic Statement of April 1989 and subsequent press statements. It will introduce an accruals system of taxing foreign source income that has been derived in low-tax countries by Australian controlled entities and has been accumulated offshore, avoiding Australian tax. Exemption proposals in the Bill will also simplify the existing foreign tax credit system (FTCS). The Bill will generally have effect from the 1990-91 income year.

An exposure draft of this Bill was released in June of this year following release of an initial draft in December last year. This Bill before the Senate is essentially the same as the June draft Bill.

Many taxpayers and tax advisers who have an interest in the proposed legislation have provided constructive comment in response to the various policy documents and drafts of the legislation released over the last two years.

As a consequence of this consultative process quite a number of significant changes were made between 1988 and 1990 to accommodate legitimate major concerns. For example, the control rule and active income exemption provided in the Bill were not policy features of the consultative document released in May 1988.

These and other policy changes have added considerably to the length and complexity of the Bill but in general they have been made to take account of the genuine concerns expressed by those Australians to whom the legislation will apply.

There were some proposed changes that the Government could not accept because they would have left untouched tax avoidance opportunities the Government is seeking to close, or were inconsistent with the policy underlying the existing foreign tax credit system.
The Government is firmly committed to these measures which will help significantly in the fight against tax avoidance.

For the great majority of Australians, those who do not have investments in offshore trusts and controlled foreign companies, this legislation will have no direct impact. There will be some beneficial effects for business in the exemptions and simplification of the FTCS.

Development of a comprehensive system for taxing foreign income has been under way for some time. Under the law as it existed before this Government introduced the FTCS Australian residents were exempt from tax in Australia on their foreign source income provided that income was taxed overseas, even if the income was subject only to a nominal rate of tax.

As a first step towards removing the bias that had encouraged Australians to invest in offshore tax havens rather than in their own country, this Government introduced the foreign tax credit system commencing from the 1987-88 income year. The system enables foreign income to be subject to Australian tax when it is remitted to Australia, with a credit being allowed for any foreign tax paid.

It was acknowledged in the 1985 tax reform papers that the tax leakage through the use of tax havens would be closed off only if the FTCS was supported by a regime for taxing foreign source income derived in low-tax countries and being diverted and accumulated offshore in foreign companies and trusts.
A number of other countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and New Zealand have already introduced similar measures to tax foreign source income on an accruals basis.
I will now turn to the more detailed aspects of the Bill.
Controlled Foreign Companies

The main feature of this Bill is the controlled foreign company measures. Their aim is to attribute to Australian residents, with some exceptions, certain income derived by a non-resident company that is controlled by Australian residents, unless the company is subject to a tax system comparable to Australia's or is predominantly engaged in active business.

A foreign company will be a controlled foreign company, or CFC, where five or fewer Australian residents own, or are entitled to acquire, 50 per cent or more of the interests in the company. The interest of a resident for this purpose will include both the direct and indirect interests of the resident and those of the resident's associates. Alternatively, a non-resident company will be a CFC if five or fewer residents have actual control of the company regardless of their shareholdings.

There is a difference between the treatment accorded to non-resident companies in listed (i.e. comparable-taxing) countries and unlisted countries. Even where a non-resident company in an unlisted country is controlled by a small number of Australian residents its income or gains will not be attributed if the CFC's ``tainted'' income is less than 5 per cent of its total income. In other words, the measures will not apply if the CFC is predominately engaged in active business. However, if it fails the test, the tainted income of the CFC will be attributed to the relevant Australian residents. The other income is not attributed and will be subject to Australian tax under the FTCS generally on remittance to Australia.
With CFCs resident in listed countries, low-taxed income may be attributed to certain of the CFC's Australian shareholders where:
- it is tainted income that benefits from a tax concession of a kind that is to be prescribed by the income tax regulations and fails the active income test;
-- in other cases the income is from sources outside the country of residence that is not taxed by any comparable tax country; or
- the company derives certain categories of trust income.
The countries that are to be treated as comparable tax countries, and the concessions that are to be treated as designated tax concessions, will be listed in the income tax regulations.

Tainted income includes the types of income that are readily able to be shifted to a foreign tax jurisdiction. These consist of passive income (such as dividends, interest, royalties and most kinds of gains on the disposal of assets) and business income from transactions with Australian residents and related parties.

The assessable income of a shareholder who is an attributable taxpayer will include the taxpayer's share of the attributable income of the CFC for an accounting year of the CFC that commenced on or after 1 July 1990 and ended during the taxpayer's year of income.

In most cases the residents who will be taxed are those who, alone or with associates, directly or indirectly hold an interest of 10 per cent or more in the CFC as at the end of the CFC's accounting year.
Foreign Tax Credit System
The introduction of the accruals tax measures provides an opportunity to simplify certain aspects of the existing FTCS.

Accordingly, with effect from the commencement of the 1990-91 income year, an exemption is to be provided for non-portfolio dividends received by Australian companies from companies resident in comparable tax countries. A dividend will be a non-portfolio dividend where the Australian company that received the dividend has a voting interest of at least 10 per cent in the foreign company. It will not be necessary that the foreign company be a CFC.

Further, the Bill provides that a dividend received by an Australian company from a company resident in an unlisted (non-comparable-tax) country will be exempt where the dividend is paid out of income that has been comparably taxed in a listed country or income that has already been included in assessable income in Australia.
Generally, other dividends are to continue to be assessable and subject to relief measures along the lines of the existing FTCS.

The FTCS will also be modified to exempt from income tax, with effect from the commencement of the 1990-91 income year, the income or profits of a resident company derived in carrying on a business at or through a permanent establishment located in a listed country, except to the extent that the income or profits was not taxed (or is concessionally) taxed by any listed country.

Income of a resident company derived at or through a permanent establishment that is not located in a listed country is to continue to be subject to income tax, as is any branch income derived by a non-corporate taxpayer. Where foreign tax has been paid on branch income which is still assessable, a credit will continue to be allowed under the FTCS.

A number of technical amendments to the FTCS will also be made generally to accommodate the interaction of the accruals tax and the existing FTCS. These relate mainly to the definition of the classes of income, exemption of dividends paid out of attributed income, carry-forward of excess credits, and quarantining of losses and credits.
Non-Resident Trusts

Another significant feature of this Bill is the transferor tax measures. These attribute income of non-resident trusts in low-tax countries to Australian residents who have, either directly or indirectly, transferred property or services to the trusts.

In the case of a discretionary trust that was in existence on 12 April 1989, an exemption from these measures will be available to a transferor if neither the transferor nor an associate of the transferor was able to control the trust on or after 12 April 1989. In this context, the term``control'' is given a wide meaning.

The attributable income of a non-resident trust estate that is not a resident of a listed country is to be the whole of the net income of the trust. In the case of a trust that is a resident of a listed country the attributable income will be limited to that part of the net income of the trust that benefits from a designated tax concession.
In both cases a deduction will be given for certain amounts that have been, or will be, subject to full taxation in Australia or in a listed country.

A deemed rate of return based generally on the value of property or services transferred to an offshore trust will be included in the assessable income of the transferor where the Commissioner is satisfied that the transferor is unable to obtain the information necessary to compute a trust's income according to Australian tax law.

Attributable income of a trust estate that has been included in the assessable income of a transferor will be exempt from tax in the hands of a beneficiary to whom that income is subsequently distributed.
Additional tax on certain trust distributions

To the extent that a resident beneficiary's assessable income for the 1990-91, or a subsequent income year, includes a distribution by a non-resident trust estate of income of previous years that has neither been attributed to a transferor nor taxed to the trustee or a beneficiary at tax rates comparable to Australia's, the beneficiary is to be liable, in certain circumstances, to pay an additional tax in the nature of an interest charge in respect of that amount. This measure will achieve a parity with resident trust estates, the net income of which is liable to tax either in the hands of the trustee or the beneficiaries in the income year it is derived. The charge is to be formally imposed by the Taxation (Interest on Non-resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990.
Additional tax in respect of income that accumulated in a non-resident trust prior to the beginning of the 1990-91 income year of the trust will accrue only from 1 July 1990.
Certain family arrangements

The transferor tax measures will not apply in relation to an offshore trust that is solely for the benefit of family members in necessitous circumstances or is a family arrangement established under a court order following a divorce or separation. The beneficiaries of these trusts should all be non-residents.
Winding up of existing trusts

As an incentive to wind up non-resident discretionary trusts that were in existence on 12 April 1989 and to which a resident had transferred property or services prior to that date, a rebate of tax will be available so that the rate of Australian tax on distributions of income made after 12 April 1989 and before 30 June 1991 does not exceed 10 per cent. The rebate will apply only if all of the trust's accumulated income and corpus are distributed, and the trust is wound up before 30 June 1991.
Keeping of Records

An attributable taxpayer in relation to a CFC or a non-resident trust will be required to keep records that show how the CFC or transferor tax measures apply to the taxpayer. Generally, the records must be maintained for five years.
Information held Offshore

The Bill will authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to issue an offshore information notice in respect of information or documents held offshore. The proposed measures give 90 days to comply and the Commissioner can extend this time limit in special circumstances. Where the information or documents is not supplied there is no provision for a penalty or prosecution. Rather, the information or documents may not be used by the taxpayer as evidence to dispute an assessment. The approach adopted in this provision is similar to that taken in the United States and Canadian tax laws and is aimed at ensuring the timely provision of all the information and documents needed by the Commissioner to get the full and correct picture of the transactions being examined.

In view of the significance of such a provision, the operation of proposed section 264A will be kept under review to ensure that its objectives are met and that the rights of affected taxpayers are adequately protected.
Changes from Draft Bill

I should mention that the Bill varies in some respects from the draft that was released in June 1990. The broad thrust of these changes is to remove tax avoidance opportunities and provide relief in certain circumstances where double taxation could have occurred due to the application of the proposed measures. Some of the amendments relate to cases where double taxation could have arisen on a change of residence of a CFC or in relation to transfers of profits between companies. The amendments reflect the willingness of this Government to address genuine taxpayer concerns on an ongoing basis.

However, the Government is committed to the measures contained in this Bill as they will ensure a more equitable tax system. The Government is also committed to ensuring that these measures operate as intended.
Not all of the announced changes have been included in the Bill. The Government intends addressing the most urgent of these in an amending Bill to be introduced late in the Budget Sittings.

Some of the amendments are the result of the close monitoring of avoidance techniques that are being developed to frustrate the intent of the proposed measures. An example of this type of amendment is the redefinition of a non-resident family trust that is to be exempt from the accruals tax measures. Similarly, the exception from the deemed dividend provisions provided earlier for the investment by a CFC in the share capital of a wholly owned subsidiary is to be withdrawn if that subsidiary is being used to provide designated benefits to its associates.
Mr President, implementation of these measures will require consequential amendments to two other Acts.
Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953
The Bill will amend the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as a consequence of the changes to the classes of income that are to apply for the purposes of the foreign tax credit system.
Taxation Administration Act 1953

The Bill will also amend the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to ensure that a person cannot be prosecuted in respect of a statement made in a document produced to the Commissioner in response to an offshore information notice or under the active income test substantiation provisions.
Financial Impact

The likely direct revenue gain resulting from the introduction of the accruals system of taxing foreign source income is difficult to determine. This is particularly so in the initial years because of the variation in CFCs' accounting periods and taxpayers' years of income; the branch exemptions; and the tax exemption for non-portfolio dividends received by resident companies from a company that is a resident of a country with a tax system comparable to Australia's.

Estimating is made more difficult because it is not known to what extent non-resident discretionary trusts will be subject to the transferor tax measures or to what extent resident controllers will take advantage of the 10 per cent final tax liability by winding up before 1 July 1991.

While the revenue gains in 1990-91 are not expected to be significant, it is anticipated that the direct revenue gain will increase to within the range of $60 million to $70 million in 1993-94 after the full impact of these measures takes effect. In addition, the domestic tax base is expected to increase but the revenue impact cannot be quantified at this stage.
I present the consolidated Explanatory Memorandum for this Bill and the Taxation (Interest on Non-resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Taxation (Interest on Non-Resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990

Mr President, this Bill will impose an interest charge on non-resident trust distributions that are included in the assessable income of a resident beneficiary where the trust income has neither been subject to tax on a current basis, nor on an attribution basis under the transferor tax measures of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990. The interest is to be calculated by reference to the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1990
This Bill proposes three substantive changes to the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

The first will provide the facility for the determination of different Volware prices for different oil producing regions, which is consequential on proposed amendments to the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987 which are contained in the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990.
The second will incorporate into the Act a previously notified excise tariff proposal which alters the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) with effect from 1 April 1990 .

The third will effect a technical correction to the definition of `new oil', to ensure that oil which has been produced from two reservoirs in the Bass Strait since 1 July 1980 and which has been excisable at the `old' oil rate, does not inadvertently become `new oil', and thereby subject to a free rate of duty.
Volware Amendments

The purpose of the proposed amendments in clauses 4 to 8 and clause 10 of the Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act to enable the calculation of different prices for sales of crude oil from different oil producing regions. These prices are required for the purpose of determining excise liability for excisable oil.

As from 1 January 1988, when the decision to deregulate the oil market and to terminate the import parity pricing basis for levying excise was implemented, crude oil prices for the purposes of calculating excise liability have been determined by the Minister for Resources (or his delegate) under the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987 on the basis of the volume weighted average of realised (Volware) prices of sales of crude oil in a calendar month.

As the principal Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act applies to offshore areas producing excisable petroleum, its application has effectively been confined to the Bass Strait producing region. The second reading speech to the principal Act in 1987 noted that production from areas onshore would become excisable in the event that production exceeded the 30 million barrel excise exempt limit, and that the price basis for excising such onshore oil production would be considered at the appropriate time.
Indications are that cumulative production from the Jackson oilfield located in south west Queensland will now exceed 30 million barrels, and hence production above this limit will become excisable.

The calculation of separate Volware prices for different oil producing regions is necessary to prevent inequities in excise liability. These inequities arise from the fact that the realised prices of crude oil from different sources have been observed to differ and hence there are direct implications for the excise payable. In effect, those producers with lower realised prices would pay relatively more of the excise liability than those with higher realised prices if a combined Volware price were used as the basis for excise liability. This is the case for Jackson and Bass Strait production.

The Bill therefore provides for an effective and equitable system of collecting excise on crude oil production by enabling the calculation of different Volware prices for different oil producing regions.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The excise duty for naturally occurring LPG is adjusted six monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the LPG excise policy announced in april 1980. The excise rate is calculated as 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne. The realised price is calculated as a weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the immediately preceding 6 months.

Under the petroleum excise arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987, LPG produced from onshore fields is exempt from excise, so the excise now only applies to offshore fields in production in August 1977. On this basis Bass Strait is the only area that attracts excise on the production of naturally occurring LPG. No excise is payable on refinery-produced LPG.

Clause 9 of the Bill will amend the excise rate with effect from 1 April 1990 to $5.78 per kilolitre, an increase from the previous free rate set on 1 April and 1 October 1989. The increase reflects the higher export prices obtained for this product over the six months to March 1990.
`New' Oil Definition Amendments

The purpose of the amendments in clause 3 of the Bill is to correct an anomaly in the definition of ``new'' oil from the date in 1984 when amendments made to the excise tariff act 1921 relating to ``new'' oil classifications were first introduced into the Act.

At the time the 1984 amendments were enacted, the Government had intended to preserve the effect of decisions made prior to 1 July 1984 under excise by-law number 78. That by-law contained provisions that were used to determine whether an oil discovery was eligible for ``new'' oil status, and hence concessional excise treatment on any crude oil production. This intention was clearly indicated by the Government when it announced in June 1983 that it intended to amend the ``new'' oil excise arrangements with effect from 1 July 1983.

The Government has recently become aware that the amendments introduced in 1984 do not legally preserve the validity of decisions on ``new'' oil applications made prior to 1 July 1983. The effect is that in one case, a decision made prior to 1983 to refuse a ``new'' oil classification on certain reservoirs could now be effectively reversed, with the effect that the companies could receive an unintended windfall, possibly up to $200 million.

In order to avoid payment of refunds on that oil, and not provide an unintended windfall to the companies concerned, the legislative changes proposed in clause 3 of the Bill have retrospective effect to 1 July 1984.

The retrospectivity will legally remove any Commonwealth liability to refund any duties paid in respect of production from the reservoirs. In effect, what has been paid will, by force of the amendment, be the correct amount of duty payable.

All producers had accepted the pre July 1983 classification arrangements and associated decisions and paid excise at the appropriate rate without protest from that time up until 1 March of this year. For that reason, the Government considers any changes made now to the ``new'' oil definition that have the effect of ensuring that the oil classifications made prior to 1 July 1983 remain binding should be seen as `declaratory' in nature that is, the changes will only ratify what the industry and Government had always expected to have been the legal position.
Financial Impact Statement
Volware Amendments

The amendments will enable excise to be collected from a field in an oil producing region that will become subject to the excise regime after that field has produced more than 30 million barrels of crude oil. The Jackson field is expected to exceed that limit in 1990/91. Other fields, including the Saladin field in Western Australia and potentially the Wanaea and Cossack fields on the North West shelf could become excisable in future years. No specific figure however can be put on the additional excise revenue that might be collected from oil producing regions subject to the excise regime in 1990/91 as that figure is dependent on both the level of production and the price received for that production, which are unknown.
LPG Amendments

The increase in the excise rate for LPG (from free to $5.78 per kilolitre on and from 1 April 1990) is estimated will result in the collection of about $9m in excise receipts in the 12 months commencing 1 April 1990.
`New oil' Definition Amendments

The correction of the `new oil' definition will remove a potential liability of the Commonwealth to repay some of the duty which has been paid on oil produced from the tuna field in the Bass Strait since 1 July 1984. But for the amendments, the extent of that liability might be in the vicinity of $200 million.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Customs Tariff Amendment Bill
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1990, which is now before the House contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. I will briefly outline those amendments.
Firstly, Clause 11 of the Bill is an administrative requirement to ensure that certain amendments contained in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1989 have due effect.

Schedules One, Two and Three contain minor administrative amendments. Schedule One is operative on and from 1 July 1988 and amends Note 4 to Chapter 28 to align it with the international harmonised system. It also provides a free rate of duty for certain articles of rubber apparel. This rate was previously applied by the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Act 1988, as a result of the Government's 1988 May Economic Statement.

Schedule Two, having effect from 1 March 1989, contains an amendment to the text of subheading 5212.12.20 and also extends the coverage of Item 40a in Schedule 4 to include lightweight wool fabrics of headings 5111 and 5112.

Schedule Three validates a rate of two and a half per cent for certain straw and fodder balers of Canadian origin and amends Item 44 in Schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 to ensure that the provisions of this item encompass goods of New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Forum Island and developing country origin. These changes operate on and from the 1 July 1989.

Schedule Four to this Bill removes Items 36c and 38b in Schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 as sunset entry provisions of this legislation expired on 31 December 1989. The changes take effect from 1 January 1990.
Schedule Five operates on and from 31 March 1990. These amendments:

are made in the context of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and insert new quota tender and tender extension duty rates for TCF goods for the period 1 March 1990 to 28 February 1991 following the determination of rates under the 1990 tender quota scheme;
delete New Zealand rates of duty for certain plastic coated fabrics of heading 5903 under the accelerated arrangements of the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement; and
amend Note 3 to Schedule 5 to allow the incorporation of badges, labels, logos, and the like in apparel without the application of separate tariff treatment.

Schedule Six removes redundant duty rates from those subheadings where phasing rates have been fully implemented. There has been some amalgamation of national subheadings where the duty rates were the same. Levels of assistance have not been affected by these changes which took effect from 1 July 1990.

Schedule Seven removes Item 1 in Schedule 4 and has the effect of requiring government departments to pay an administrative charge equal to customs duty on their imports. This arrangement has effect on and from 1 October 1990.
Schedule Eight will operate from seven days after this Bill is given royal assent and contains:
amendments to Schedule One to take account of changes in the names of a number of countries or places which qualify for developing country preference;
the introduction of a free rate of duty for protein concentrates of subheading 2106.10.10;
the levying of duty on the spirituous component of mixed beverages of subheading 2206.00.90;
the removal of duty from coal tar and pitch of subheadings 2706.00.10 and 2708.10.00;
An amendment which provides a free rate of duty for parts for programmable controllers of subheading 8538.90.20;
changes to the treatment of diesel powered ride-on motor mowers which emanate from the Industries Assistance Commission's report on the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries;
the removal of a redundant paragraph in Item 42b in schedule four; and
a number of administrative changes of a minor nature which are the result of previous legislative amendments.
Financial Impact

The value of the tender quota allocation for 1990/1991 has been raised by twenty per cent above 1989/1990 levels and the increased imports are expected to raise an additional $101.6 million in customs duty.

It is difficult to predict the amount of customs duty which will be foregone by allowing protein concentrates to be imported duty free as separate import figures were not kept for the current financial year. However based on past figures and applied pro rata to current imports it is expected that the amount of customs duty involved will be about $350,000.
Reducing the duty rates to free on pitch and coal tar will reduce revenue in a full financial year by $700,000 and $127,000 respectively.

The cost of Commonwealth departments paying the equivalent of customs duty is budget neutral. This change places public service managers on the same footing as private enterprise managers whereby purchasing decisions will be made on the full duty paid price. Australian industry is expected to benefit.
The overall effect of other changes contained in this Bill are not considered to be significant.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members.
I commend the Bill.
PETROLEUM EXCISE (PRICES) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987 to enable the calculation of a volume weighted average of realised prices of sales of crude oil, referred to as the VOLWARE price. This calculation is required for the purpose of determining excise liability for excisable oil produced outside of the Bass Strait producing area, including the Jackson oilfield located in south west Queensland.
The powers of this Bill are integral to the collection of crude oil excise under the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and Excise Act 1901.

As from 1 January 1988, when the decision to deregulate the oil market and to terminate the import parity pricing basis for levying excise was implemented, crude oil prices for the purposes of calculating excise liability have been determined by the Minister for Resources (or his delegate) under the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987 on the basis of the volume weighted average of realised (VOLWARE) prices of sales of crude oil in a calendar month. As the principal Act applies to offshore areas producing excisable petroleum, its application has effectively been confined to the Bass Strait producing region. The second reading speech to the principal Act noted that production from areas onshore would become excisable in the event that production exceeded the 30m barrel excise free limit, and that the price basis for excising such onshore oil production would be considered at the appropriate time.
Indications are that cumulative production from the Jackson oilfield will exceed 30m barrels early in 1990-91, and hence production above this limit will become excisable.

The calculation of separate VOLWARE prices for different producing regions is necessary to prevent inequities in excise liability. These inequities arise from the fact that the realised prices of crude oil from different sources have been observed to differ and hence there are direct implications for the excise payable. In effect, those producers with lower realised prices would pay relatively more of the excise liability than those with higher realised prices if a combined VOLWARE price were used as the basis for excise liability. This is the case for Jackson and Bass Strait production.

In order to facilitate the calculation of a VOLWARE price to determine excise liability for the Jackson oilfield, it is necessary to widen the definition of producer in the principal Act to include onshore producers. Amendments are also required to enable the calculation of a separate VOLWARE price for the Bass Strait and Jackson producing regions and for the description of each producing region to be prescribed in the regulations to the Act.

The amendments have been framed in a way that will enable regions additional to Jackson and Bass Strait to be listed separately in the regulations in the event that production from within other regions becomes liable for excise.

This Bill therefore provides for an effective and equitable system of collecting excise on crude oil production at Jackson. The amount of excise that will be generated from the Jackson oilfield will be dependent on the level of production. If production were to be maintained at current levels, excise of about $0.35m might be expected in a full year.
Consequential changes of a minor nature are required to the Excise Tariff Act 1921. These are incorporated in proposed amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to honourable senators.
