SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -On Monday I brought to the attention of the Senate the possible misappropriation of between $5.3m and $5.7m from Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd during the time that it was receiving Commonwealth money and supposedly being monitored by Senator Richardson's Department. I now intend to reveal where the money ended up. For this purpose I seek leave to table an information memorandum for prospective purchasers of the Timbertech Group prepared by the receivers and also the balance sheet as at 30 June 1988 for an associated company in Kyogle, National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd.
—Is leave granted?
—I certainly won't oppose this, but it would have been courteous if Senator O'Chee had shown it to us.

—Before proceeding further, however, I should comment on the statement tabled by Senator Richardson on Tuesday. There are a number of inaccuracies and inconsistencies in the statement which clearly show that either Senator Richardson or Mrs Kelly still do not understand the issue or are deliberately trying to hide the full implications of Senator Richardson's incompetence.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 2 of the statement, Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd is described as a division of National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd. This is not true. In fact, National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd is a partially owned subsidiary of Plywood and Plastic. But then, given that Senator Richardson was not aware that $5.3m had disappeared, it does not surprise me that he does not know which company owns what.
On page 4 of the statement it is claimed that the assistance agreement was:
. . . a list of things that the money provided by the Commonwealth could be spent on-it did not canvass the possible things that the money should not be spent on.

In other words, the Government is admitting that it took no steps to include in the agreement anything to prevent the money being misused-not one word in writing to protect the $7.6m of Commonwealth money. Contrary to Mrs Kelly's assertion, such negative covenants are normal commercial practice amongst responsible lenders.

The only thing that the Commonwealth can even claim to have done is to mention to the company in its negotiations that expenditure beyond the list would not be acceptable under the terms of the agreement. Well, even if we accept that-and there is nothing to prove it-then the company clearly failed to observe the terms of the agreement and Senator Richardson was totally incorrect in saying that the company had not met all the conditions required of it.

There are two other points to be made regarding the statement tabled by Senator Richardson. First, the statement deliberately attempts to avoid the facts in saying that it would have been unreasonable for the Commonwealth to take a mortgage in priority to those already existing in favour of Westpac Banking Corporation and Placer Industries Ltd. Indeed, it would be, but that was not the point. My criticism was, and remains, that the Commonwealth should have taken a security over other companies in the group and not just over the assets of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. That was what Westpac did and what any other responsible lender would have done-any other responsible lender, but not the Commonwealth. I think that the Government's deliberate attempt to avoid that point is tacit acknowledgment of its negligence in this matter.

Finally, we must take note of the comments of the receivers when they say that they had difficulty preparing accounts for the group `due to the poor standard of the group's record keeping', and further:
. . . there was also a lack of fundamental reconciliations of accounts (e.g. bank reconciliation and reconciliation of inter-company loan accounts).

In view of these comments I think we have to treat with scepticism any claim by the Government that it could reasonably have been satisfied with the company's accounting. These sorts of things would have had a much higher chance of being detected had the Government required quarterly or half-yearly accounts to be presented in a timely fashion, and would certainly have been noticed if the Commonwealth had not waited until March 1990 to get around to requesting a copy of the 1989 annual accounts.

For these reasons, I totally reject the shabby and unjustified attack made by the Government on Mr Mike Seccombe of the Sydney Morning Herald, and support him in laying blame fairly and squarely at the feet of this inept Government.

Let me move on, however, to reveal where at least some of the Commonwealth's money, the taxpayers' money, went, because it does not seem to have stayed long in Ravenshoe. The key to this puzzle lies in the statement of financial position of National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd on 31 March 1990, which is contained in annexure C of the information prospectus. National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd was a company owned and operated jointly by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd and an associated company, National Plywood Company Pty Ltd. National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd had as its principal purpose the operation of a sawmill at Kyogle.

As at 31 March 1990 National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd had bank loans of $11.7m and what appear to be unsecured trade creditors in excess of $6m. On top of this it owed $7.8m to other companies in the group, one of these being Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. In short, the company in Kyogle owed $25.8m, or over $11.4m more than the value of its assets.

Let us compare this with the balance sheet for the company as at 30 June 1988 when its total operating borrowings were only $10.7m. This means that between June 1988 and March 1990 the Kyogle company borrowed a massive $15m. Where did all this go? Part of it went to build the mill in Kyogle, which was only on the drawing board in 1988 and which was completed this year. I can only assume that the rest of the money went in losses, although I think that the matter needs further investigation.

I am not pretending that all this money came directly from Ravenshoe, although between $1.5m and $2m did. The point I make though is that the company in Ravenshoe lent money to other companies in the group which, in turn, lent money to the company in Kyogle. The Ravenshoe mill appears to have been the cash cow that National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd, the company in Kyogle, lived off. The documents are all now on the public record, and people can go through them if they want. But let me just say this: A lot of money went out of Ravenshoe and north Queensland, and a lot of money went into Kyogle. A mill should have been retooled in Ravenshoe but was not, while at the same time a mill was being built in Kyogle. Honourable senators can draw their own conclusions, but all this occurred right under the nose of Senator Richardson, and he must be responsible.

Once again we come back to the inadequacy of the Commonwealth's assistance agreement. I think Mrs Kelly, in response to Mr Chaney's question yesterday, suggested that the Ravenshoe mill went into receivership because of other companies in the group. I think the Ravenshoe mill went into receivership in part as a result of what was going on in Kyogle, but if the Government had taken securities over the whole group and asked for prompt accounting, this could have been prevented. The Ravenshoe mill was bled to death because of Senator Richardson's incompetence.

But the irregularities do not stop there. It has been suggested that a $350,000 boiler purchased with Commonwealth money was sold and leased back, and that a $400,000 veneer mill was also sold. If these comments are correct, then either Senator Richardson agreed to its happening, which would be commercially inept, or he did not. If Senator Richardson did not agree to these sales, then the company clearly breached the terms of the assistance agreement and he failed to notice. Either way it is not a particularly good reflection on Senator Richardson's performance as a Minister.

In response to the very damning evidence that I have brought to light, Senator Richardson and Mrs Kelly have attempted to allege that those of us on this side have jeopardised the continued viability of the mill. Nothing could be further from the truth. The financial documents I have tabled are either public documents or are provided by the receivers to interested purchasers. None of this goes to the commercial viability of the mill, but it does go to the competence of the relevant Minister.

The only way that the continued viability of the mill can be jeopardised is if the Government does not keep its promises. By the way, the grant that the Government claims it has made still has not been received. If this grant is withdrawn, let there be no doubt about it, it will be the direct result of a decision by Mrs Kelly. It is not something that can be laid at the feet of those who want accountable government. I think that if the Minister does withdraw the money, everybody will recognise not only what a shabby little stunt that would be, but how it would be totally inconsistent with her stated concern for mill workers.

To conclude, we have seen the apparent disappearance of over $5m from the mill at Ravenshoe, combined with extensive borrowings by an associated company in Kyogle. We have seen the people of north Queensland shamefully neglected while a mill was built in New South Wales. Most importantly, we have seen grossly inept commercial practices by a Minister who refuses to accept responsibility for his actions and the people of Ravenshoe and north Queensland deserve better than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—If you want to speak every day on the adjournment, you should resign as Leader and become a back- bencher again.

—Mr Deputy President, whether I am the Leader or a back bencher will not depend on Senator Collins; it will depend on the support that I enjoy within this Party. We do not need any gratuitous advice from Senator Collins.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee raises a very serious problem, a massively seriously problem. I have been involved in the Ravenshoe problem since the 1987 election. I have seen people there being destroyed. I have sympathy for the 2 1/2 thousand people employed in the rainforest timber industry-an industry worth $33m, an industry that was destroyed by this Government. I have seen people lose their jobs, lose their businesses, lose their pride. I have made representations for these people in their claims for compensation. I have heard about their broken marriages. I have heard about teachers abusing kids because their fathers are environmental rapists-or so their teachers say. I have seen proud men lose their self-respect.

Ravenshoe was a proud town and it can continue to be a proud town if the Government meets its commitment. On 29 June 1988, Commonwealth grants and loans to a total of $7.6 were given. On 24 April 1990, the holding company and the associated company went into receivership. Of the loan $4.2m is outstanding and not all of the retooling has been completed. Ravenshoe business people are owed $220,000. Those businessmen and women supported the mill believing Senator Richardson's claim that he made in the Senate, in the Parliament of Australia, that no-one would be hurt by the World Heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought he said they would be better off.

—Senator Richardson said no-one would be hurt and no-one would be worse off. The business people extended the credit to support the mill because they believed that that was the only way in which their town could survive. It was all they could do as citizens to hold together a tiny little town that depended on one mill for its survival and its sustenance. If the businesses did not supply that mill, the town would go down. Unless the Government acts, the town will go down.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the company owes the Commonwealth $4.2m. The Government asked for a report on 19 June and 14 September. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, wrote on 19 June this year and 14 September and asked the receivers for a report. As far back as 19 June people were worried about where the money was going. I questioned Senator Richardson, as did Senator Macdonald, on 19 September. We were told that the report would be here in a couple of days. Why did it take from 19 June to 19 September-three months-to get that report? A further report was sent on 25 September.

We had to wait three months for the Minister to come up with that report. The Minister and Senator Richardson representing the Minister have assured us that all the conditions of the agreement were met. How many times has he stood up in this Senate and said that all the agreements have been met? Either Senator Richardson has not been informed by the Minister or-I will not give the other conclusion.

Today I pointed out, and Senator O'Chee just mentioned in his contribution, that $750,000 worth of machinery was removed from the plant. A boiler worth $300,000, that was paid for by the Commonwealth, was sold back to Westpac Banking Corporation and leased back to the mill. A veneer mill worth at least $400,000 was sold off.

In 1988-89 the mill was a viable, profitable, going concern which showed a profit of about $300,000, employing 48 people. It would be still making a profit if the Government money had been spent properly: supporting the mill, supporting the people in the town, supporting the employers and supporting the unionists who pay their $160-odd a year and who send people to this Parliament to represent them. The mill was left without capital, without sufficient tools, with a list of unsecured creditors, with unpaid contractors and with unpaid private land-holders who had sold their timber to the mill and had not been paid. It was left without a feather to fly with and that is why it has proceeded down the road to bankruptcy.

The Government cannot walk away from its responsibility. The Government may say that it gave that money to a particular company, but that company never put the money into the mill. The Commonwealth Government had the responsibility to the people of Ravenshoe, the timber workers, the town-not to the company that it lent the money to. By walking away from its responsibility, writing out a blank cheque, the Government took a Pontius Pilate attitude: it washed its hands of the whole problem.

Some of the money that should have been spent on supporting the mill at Ravenshoe has ended up supplying another mill in Kyogle. Senator Richardson has not honoured his commitment concerning the World Heritage listing. I do not believe Senator Richardson is a dishonourable man. Senator Richardson made a commitment to the people of Ravenshoe in the World Heritage listing who were disadvantaged by a Government decision to declare an area of north Queensland a rainforest or World Heritage listing. He promised the people of Kyogle nothing; yet they are the people who got some advantage.

The Government had given money to support its promise to the people who had lost their jobs, their homes and their future. The fact that this matter was referred to the Attorney-General is sufficient proof that this commitment may not have been honoured by the company to which the money was given. The Government's responsibility was to ensure that the mill was kept viable. It did not allow any money to go there and it could not perform and make a profit.

I want to turn to what I believe is an outrageous suggestion by Senator Richardson today. He said-and I paraphrase him-that, because Senator Macdonald, Senator O'Chee and I have exposed this matter in the Federal Parliament of Australia and we performed our duties as we have been elected to do, the people of Ravenshoe would suffer. That can never be sustained or supported. I do not think this Government would ever support a suggestion such as that. I hope it never will, because, if it does, the wrath of the people will descend on it. This Government is supposed to support the working man and woman of Australia. Let us see it put its money where its mouth is in the next couple of days.
